quiz.name: 2026 CFA Program LI Mock Exam B Session 2
quiz.subtopic: 2026 CFA Program LI Mock Exam B Session 2
instructions:
CFA Level 1 Mock Exam Instructions

This CFA Level I mock exam (Session 2) is in English and contains 90 multiple-choice questions. You will have 2 hours and 15 minutes to complete the exam and review your answers. 

Before You Begin

Please note the following in regards to this examination:

  • International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) apply unless otherwise noted.
  • "The Code" refers to the CFA Institute Code of Ethics.
  • "The Standards" refers to the CFA Institute Standards of Professional Conduct.
  • "GIPS® standards" refers to the Global Investment Performance Standards.

How to Answer Questions

  • Each question is numbered and includes multiple-choice options (lettered A, B, C).
  • For each question:
    • Decide which answer is best.
    • Select the corresponding letter.
    • Click 'Next' to move to the next question.
  • You may:
    • Select only one answer per question.
    • Skip questions or return to questions by selecting the ‘Previous’ or the ‘Next’ buttons.

After Completing the Exam

  • Click 'Submit' when you are finished.
  • Once submitted, you may review all questions and your selected answers.
  • Only selected responses will be scored.
  • Your score will reflect the number of correct answers only.
    • No penalty for incorrect answers.
    • It is to your advantage to answer every question, even if you are unsure of the correct answer.
  • If you finish early, use the remaining time to review questions you are unsure about.

Click the 'Begin' button when you are ready to start the mock exam.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2023.01-Equity-Glover-17
entry.itemBody: Which of the following industry classification schemes covers private companies, non-profits, and government entities?

answerFeedback.56c137ea-2ccb-4aa1-8292-ec3f7afd9c31: Incorrect because GICS and ICB cover public companies, while TRBC also covers private companies, non-profits, and government entities.
answerFeedback.b0bb2ec6-34eb-4bf8-b8c6-ece85096c960: Correct because GICS and ICB cover public companies, while TRBC also covers private companies, non-profits, and government entities.
answerFeedback.e9a280e9-bc19-4b0a-a6ea-7b82aeb04baf: Incorrect because GICS and ICB cover public companies, while TRBC also covers private companies, non-profits, and government entities.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-PM-Tsependa-02
entry.itemBody: Which of the following sections of an IPS most likely explains the steps to be taken to keep the IPS current?

answerFeedback.0fa2f687-75c9-4192-91d0-0f8597f77776: Correct because the Procedures section explains the steps to take to keep the IPS current and the procedures to follow to respond to various contingencies.
answerFeedback.a44c096c-f78e-41c7-ba04-2cde5975aead: Incorrect because the Statement of Duties and Responsibilities section details the duties and responsibilities of the client, the custodian of the client’s assets, and the investment managers, and not the steps to keep the IPS current.
answerFeedback.f65b4680-d518-46f5-ad37-e213dd5386ba: Incorrect because the Investment Guidelines section provides information about how policy should be executed (e.g., on the permissible use of leverage and derivatives) and on specific types of assets excluded from investment, if any, and not the steps to keep the IPS current.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Derivs-Lin-08
entry.itemBody: A swap is most likely similar to a series of forward contracts when:

answerFeedback.5f0cc3b6-d2da-4764-a79c-34c7511bfca5: Incorrect because each forward contract will be created at the fixed price that corresponds to the fixed price of a swap of the same maturity with payments made at the same dates as the series of forward contracts. That means that some of the forward contracts would have positive values and some would have negative values, but their combined values would equal zero. Therefore, a swap contract is similar to a series of long forward contracts of which some have positive values and some have negative values, but long forward contracts are not matched with the short forward contracts at each swap payment date.
answerFeedback.b8467920-cc3f-4ee7-b1df-043ca66b22de: Incorrect because a swap is not similar to a series of forward contracts when all the forward contracts have the same maturity date.
answerFeedback.f8fd683d-227b-4807-8409-c6e0bec93b62: Correct because each forward contract will be created at the fixed price that corresponds to the fixed price of a swap of the same maturity with payments made at the same dates as the series of forward contracts. That means that some of the forward contracts would have positive values and some would have negative values, but their combined values would equal zero.

choices.itemBody: A. the combined value of all forward contracts is zero.
B. all the forward contracts have the same maturity date.
C. the value of the long forward contracts are matched with the value of the short forward contracts at each swap payment date.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-PM-Chua-05
entry.itemBody: The expected return calculated using the CAPM is least likely used for:

answerFeedback.51ec1cc2-9598-45f7-84de-cacfb0b53ee1: Incorrect because setting fair insurance premiums is a valid application of the CAPM-derived expected return. The CAPM is used for estimating expected return in many scenarios. Other examples include calculating the cost of capital for regulated companies by regulatory commissions and setting fair insurance premiums.
answerFeedback.660e8609-c163-4126-b91e-d5c8a08c7cfe: Correct because the CAPM-derived expected return is not used for forecasting the internal rate of return of a project, but instead is used as a hurdle rate or cost of capital for discounting forecast cash flows to arrive at a valuation. Given an asset's systematic risk, the expected return can be calculated using the CAPM. Recall that the price of an asset is the sum of all future cash flows discounted at the required rate of return, where the discount rate or the required rate of return is commensurate with the asset's risk. On the other hand, the internal rate of return is the discount rate at which the sum of present values of the project's cash flows will equal zero.
answerFeedback.a6a27444-f622-4776-a138-21b6fea7103c: Incorrect because determining the economic feasibility of projects is a valid application of the CAPM-derived expected return. The required rate of return from the CAPM is also used for capital budgeting and determining the economic feasibility of projects.

choices.itemBody: B. determining the economic feasibility of projects.
C. forecasting the internal rate of return of a project.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-Alt-Lee-22
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is considered an economic infrastructure asset?

answerFeedback.0c5cd57e-2458-4e6a-bf04-934ed8d8daef: Incorrect because educational assets are an example of social infrastructure assets. Social infrastructure assets are directed toward human activities and include such assets as educational, health care, social housing, and correctional facilities, with the focus on providing, operating, and maintaining the asset infrastructure.
answerFeedback.daacb07c-972c-4c10-b2bb-e6b602da64c6: Incorrect because health care assets are an example of social infrastructure assets. Social infrastructure assets are directed toward human activities and include such assets as educational, health care, social housing, and correctional facilities, with the focus on providing, operating, and maintaining the asset infrastructure.
answerFeedback.f3c31a05-e13c-48ef-be01-2395f827fe87: Correct because economic infrastructure assets support economic activity through transportation assets, information and communication technology (ICT) assets, and utility and energy assets. ICT assets include infrastructure that stores, broadcasts, and transmits information or data, such as telecommunication towers and data centers.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Derivs-Agarwal-02
entry.itemBody: A hedge portfolio consists of underlying assets and derivatives on those underlying assets. In the absence of arbitrage, the portfolio is expected to earn:

answerFeedback.0521b35b-5d04-4d96-b575-2a34fba1129d: Correct because derivatives usually take their values from the underlying by constructing a hypothetical combination of the derivatives and the underlyings that eliminates risk. This combination is typically called a hedge portfolio. With the risk eliminated, it follows that the hedge portfolio should earn the risk-free rate.
answerFeedback.17957354-cb34-49d1-92ad-559ed94126fc: Incorrect because derivatives usually take their values from the underlying by constructing a hypothetical combination of the derivatives and the underlyings that eliminates risk. With the risk eliminated, it follows that the hedge portfolio should earn the risk-free rate, and not zero return.
answerFeedback.f9b32cf2-9983-42ce-919d-d70ae9f6dd24: Incorrect because even though the portfolio consists of underlyings and derivatives on those underlyings, the risk has been neutralized as it is a hedge portfolio. It follows that the return should be equal to the risk-free rate.

choices.itemBody: C. the weighted average return of the underlying assets in the portfolio.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516141
entry.itemBody: A company’s non-callable, non-convertible preferred stock that pays an annual dividend of $3.75 is currently selling at its par value of $50 per share. If the required rate of return increases by 75 bps, the preferred stock’s new price is closest to:

answerFeedback.32443670-f0bf-4005-9ea1-d2e9ad4eafd0:
Incorrect because the required return increase is incorrectly added to the current required return. Basis points are not correctly converted.

Investors’ current required return = dividend/market price = $3.75/$50 = 7.50%

New required return = 7.50% + 0.075 = 7.575%

New market price = $3.75/0.07575 = $49.50
answerFeedback.a850744e-9438-4e67-b86f-00512252b62f:
Incorrect because it mistakenly subtracts the increase in the required return from the current required return to arrive at the new required return.

Investors’ current required return = dividend/market price = $3.75/$50 = 7.50%

New required return = 7.50% – 0.75% = 6.75%

New market price = dividend / required return = $3.75/0.0675 = $55.56
answerFeedback.db9a4f5f-f912-4955-a474-d8dd1ada7a86:
Correct because:

Investors’ current required return = dividend/market price = $3.75/$50 = 7.50%

New required return = 7.50% + 0.75% = 8.25%

New market price = $3.75/0.0825 = $45.45

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-PM-Tomter-01
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements about pension plans is most accurate?

answerFeedback.4ee43b34-196f-4d40-aa3a-0e1f03c3564c: Incorrect because the risk tolerance for defined benefit pension plans will vary with the maturity of the plan, but is typically quite high.
answerFeedback.953c4256-4837-43ec-ad81-45518105eb68: Correct because defined benefit pension plans (DB plans) are company-sponsored plans that offer employees a predefined benefit on retirement. The future benefit is defined because the DB plan requires the plan sponsor to specify the obligation stated in terms of the retirement income benefits owed to participants.
answerFeedback.b2f97230-b8bc-4657-b7cb-0604d499588f: Incorrect because defined contribution pension plans are managed for individual investors, therefore the risk tolerance of each plan varies with the individual. Some individuals will be investing for growth and will therefore seek assets that have the potential for capital gains. Others, such as retirees, may need to draw an income from their assets and may therefore choose to invest more in fixed-income and dividend-paying shares. The investment needs of individuals will depend in part on their broader financial circumstances, such as their employment prospects and whether or not they own their own residence. They may also need to consider such issues as building up a cash reserve and the purchase of appropriate insurance policies before undertaking longer-term investments. The risk tolerance of an individual investor varies by individual.

choices.itemBody: A. Defined benefit plans typically have a low risk tolerance
B. Defined contribution plans typically have a high risk tolerance
C. The sponsor of a defined benefit plan specifies the obligation owed to participants

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Islam-02
entry.itemBody: Short positions have the potential for:

answerFeedback.3c8137ef-c346-40de-b15d-6fe71f7ead57: Incorrect because the potential gains on a short position are limited to no more than 100 percent whereas the potential losses are unbounded. Long positions have potentials of unbounded gains.
answerFeedback.9c6d64cd-8046-414f-956e-cf2459c6100e: Correct because the potential gains on a short position are limited to no more than 100 percent whereas the potential losses are unbounded.
answerFeedback.e96037d8-a4bd-47db-b6de-5679256017e7: Incorrect because the potential gains on a short position are limited to no more than 100 percent whereas the potential losses are unbounded.

choices.itemBody: C. both unbounded gains and unbounded losses.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09653
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a company's common stock and the market:

Current dividend per share (D0) $10.00
Beta 1.4
Expected risk-free rate of return 3%
Expected market rate of return 9%

If the growth rate of dividends is expected to be 2%, the stock's intrinsic value based on the Gordon growth model is closest to:

answerFeedback.3e9b360c-0464-4f70-bd9c-86e2ea7fc184:
Correct because the intrinsic value of a common stock is V0=D01+gr-g=D1r-g where: V0 = Intrinsic value of the stock today; r = Required rate of return on the stock; and g = Dividend growth rate.

The required rate of return on a common stock is the sum of the current expected risk-free rate plus a risk premium that equals the product of the stock's beta (a measure of non-diversifiable risk) and the market risk premium (the expected return of the market in excess of the risk-free return). Based on the information in the table and expressing the formula in alphanumeric format we have:

r = rf + β × (rm – rf). That is, r = 3% + 1.4 × (9% – 3%) = 11.4%. Therefore: V0 = $10 × (1 + 2%) / (11.4% – 2%) = 10.2 / 9.4% ≈ $108.51.
answerFeedback.5bdae430-c1a1-4361-b1d4-085a9c6f1d5f: Incorrect because D0 is used instead of D1: V0 = $10 / (11.4% – 2%) = $10 / 9.4% ≈ $106.38.
answerFeedback.c42629a2-09b7-4245-8677-9ca376b94721: Incorrect because the candidate has applied the following formula to derive the stock's intrinsic value: V0 = D1 / (rm – g) = $10 × (1 + 2%) / (9% – 2%) = 10.2 / 7% ≈ $145.71.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06182
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about an equally weighted portfolio comprised of 500 assets:

  • Average variance of the returns of the assets = 0.04
  • Average covariance between the returns of the assets = 0.01

The variance of the portfolio returns is closest to:

answerFeedback.0c97b50d-d8ce-45fb-aadd-4322f05db59d: Incorrect because it is the average variance of the assets of the portfolio, not the average covariance between the assets. For portfolios with a large number of assets, covariance among the assets accounts for almost all of the portfolio's risk.
answerFeedback.af04bf6b-57ca-4e29-90a6-a9bffe0f1072:
Correct because for portfolios with a large number of assets, covariance among the assets accounts for almost all of the portfolio's risk. Given equal weights and average variance/covariance, we can rewrite the portfolio variance as: σ p 2 = σ ¯ 2 N + N−1 N COV ¯ .

The variance of the portfolio = (0.04/500) + [(500 – 1)/500] × 0.01 = 0.00008 + 0.00998 = 0.01006 ≈ 0.01 (average covariance of returns).
answerFeedback.bfc538f7-b535-4597-9581-58ce3db9e173: Incorrect because it is the sum of the average variance of the assets of the portfolio and the average covariance between the assets. For portfolios with a large number of assets, covariance among the assets accounts for almost all of the portfolio's risk.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-PM-Zhang-06
entry.itemBody: Which of the following best describes the risk of having to make a significant price concession when selling an asset?

answerFeedback.1e68d56f-a1b6-4307-81f8-8571dc469847: Incorrect because settlement risk is the risk of loss from the settling of payments that occur just before a default. However, the stem does not refer to any default event.
answerFeedback.3807af06-9643-44f2-a961-db2a31e6c4b4: Incorrect because solvency risk is the risk that the organization does not survive or succeed because it runs out of cash, even though it might otherwise be solvent.
answerFeedback.b31cf856-57a8-4ac0-96b1-59a0f4d83f2a: Correct because liquidity risk is the risk of a significant downward valuation adjustment when selling a financial asset. In order to sell an asset, a party may need to reduce the price to a level that is less than the marked value or the seller’s assessment of the asset’s true value based on the fundamentals of the asset. In certain market conditions, the seller must make a significant price concession.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606052
entry.itemBody: You are preparing an investment policy statement for a client who manages her own successful marketing consultancy. Her annual income is approximately $500,000. She describes herself as a finance novice. Most of her savings are invested in bank term deposits and short-term government securities. In her responses to the standard risk assessment questionnaire, she strongly agrees with the statements that she “feels more comfortable putting money in a bank account than in the stock market.” Also, she “thinks of the word ‘risk’ as being a ‘loss’”. Based on this information, your client’s ability and willingness to take risk can best be described as:

answerFeedback.4b16d601-ac82-474a-b46f-f9488958cbcc: Correct. Although the client owns a successful business and has a high income, she exhibits above-average risk aversion, indicating that her ability to take risk is high, but her willingness to take risk is low.
answerFeedback.788893e8-9cd8-4c82-8af3-6fd89d98c6c4: Incorrect because her ability to take risk is high, but there is low (not high) willingness to take risk.
answerFeedback.ccab6fcf-1ba1-4185-931f-8a9b424808ad: Incorrect because her ability to take risk is high (not low), and there is low (not high) willingness to take risk.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516062
entry.itemBody: The financial systems that are operationally efficient are most likely characterized by:

answerFeedback.40e1e87d-326c-4c36-bfea-d9df828fd114: Incorrect because allocationally efficient markets, not the operationally efficient markets, are characterized by using resources where they are most valuable.
answerFeedback.91f00608-381c-426e-a740-8a85fc192f1b: Correct because operationally efficient markets are liquid markets in which the costs of arranging trades, commissions, bid–ask spreads, and order price impacts are low.
answerFeedback.af2815e2-e208-4cff-add7-50072f04835a: Incorrect because informationally efficient markets, not the operationally efficient markets, are characterized by prices that reflect fundamental values so that prices vary primarily in response to changes in fundamental values and not to demands for liquidity made by uninformed traders.

choices.itemBody: A. security prices that reflect fundamental values.
B. the use of resources where they are most valuable.
C. liquid markets with low commissions and order price impacts.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-Equity-Milosevic-08
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about an index composed of three securities:

  Security 1 Security 2 Security 3
Beginning-of-period price $50 $75 $60
End-of-period price $60 $95 $65
Shares outstanding 300 350 400

If the number of constituent shares is constant, the weighting method that results in the highest return is:

answerFeedback.4aea4b36-96f7-45f1-a411-ba84bb83dded:
Correct because the price-return under a price-weighting method is ~18.9%. That is:

Step 1: Calculate the beginning of period price = 50 + 75 +60 = 185

Step 2: Calculate the end of period price = 60 + 95 + 65 = 220

Step 3: Calculate the price return = (220/185) – 1 ~ 18.9%
answerFeedback.60500403-2ab7-40d5-bbdb-d460af2bcc92:
Incorrect because the price return under an equal-weighting method is ~18.3%. That is:

Step 1: Calculate the one period return for each security:

Security 1 = (60/50) – 1 = 20%

Security 2 = (95/75) – 1 ~ 26.7%

Security 3 = (65/60) –1 ~ 8.3%

Step 2: Calculate the total return = (20% + 26.7% + 8.3%)/3 ~ 18.3%
answerFeedback.afd1b5ad-996e-421e-afc5-4400d139831d:
Incorrect because the price return under a value-weighting method is ~ 18.4%. That is:

Step 1: Calculate the beginning of period market value = (50 × 300) + (75 × 350) + (60 × 400) = 15,000 + 26,250 + 24,000 = 65,250

Step 2: Calculate the end of period market value = (60 × 300) + (95 × 350) + (65 × 400) = 18,000 + 33,250 + 26,000 = 77,250

Step 3: Calculate the price return = end of period market value / beginning of period market minus 1 = (77,250/65,250) – 1 ~ 18.4%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-Alt-Vervloet-13
entry.itemBody: Which of the following best describes a clawback provision?  A provision that:

answerFeedback.4bcb6873-c0cf-4237-b3c1-5a93038da8e6: Incorrect because this pertains to the hurdle rate, which is a minimum rate of return, typically 8%, that the GP must exceed in order to earn the performance fee. GPs typically receive 20% of the total profit of the private equity fund net of any hard hurdle rate, in which case the GP earns fees on annual returns in excess of the hurdle rate, or net of the soft hurdle rate, in which case the fee is calculated on the entire annual gross return as long as the set hurdle is exceeded.
answerFeedback.8b4cb3d6-304e-4436-aba9-55ee83e61212: Correct because a clawback provision reflects the right of LPs to reclaim part of the GP’s performance fee. Along either waterfall path, if a GP ever accrues (or actually pays itself) an incentive fee on gains that are not yet fully realized and then subsequently gives back these gains, an investor is typically able to claw back prior incentive fee accruals and payments. Clawback provisions are usually activated when a GP exits successful deals early on but incurs losses on deals later in the fund’s life.
answerFeedback.fdb36bf0-d412-4bc4-b469-94501ca6f7c7: Incorrect because this pertains to a high-water mark. In hedge funds, fee calculations also take into account a high-water mark, which reflects the highest value used to calculate an incentive fee. A high-water mark is the highest value of the fund investment ever achieved at a performance fee crystallization date, net of fees, by the individual LP. A high-water mark clause states that a hedge fund manager must recuperate declines in value from the high-water mark before performance fees can be charged on newly generated profits. The use of high-water marks protects clients from paying twice for the same performance.

choices.itemBody: A. protects clients from paying twice for the same performance.
B. reflects the right of limited partners to reclaim part of the general partner's performance fee.
C. represents the minimum rate of return that must be exceeded in order to earn a performance fee.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-Deriv-Lamba-05
entry.itemBody: Based on put–call–forward parity, a trader can replicate a short forward position with a:

answerFeedback.3edbd9bf-a129-45f0-9db4-1e3efb8e5020: Incorrect because the cost of the fiduciary call must equal the cost of the synthetic pro­tective put, giving us what is referred to as put–call–forward parity, F0(T)/(1 + r)T + p0 = c0 + X/(1 + r)T. This implies: –F0(T)/(1 + r)T = p0 – c0 – X/(1 + r)T. So, a short forward position can be replicated with a long (not short) a put, short a call, and short a bond.
answerFeedback.5f5b59f3-b182-4800-a739-60acb8fdf950: Incorrect because the cost of the fiduciary call must equal the cost of the synthetic protective put, giving us what is referred to as put–call–forward parity, F0(T)/(1 + r)T + p0 = c0 + X/(1 + r)T. This implies: –F0(T)/(1 + r)T = p0 – c0 – X/(1 + r)T. So, a short forward position can be replicated with a long (not short) a put, short (not long) a call, and short (not long) a bond.
answerFeedback.98f3b5cb-b8e2-4fd9-86e2-8295ea8a1d7b: Correct because the cost of the fiduciary call must equal the cost of the synthetic pro­tective put, giving us what is referred to as put–call–forward parity, F0(T)/(1 + r)T + p0 = c0 + X/(1 + r)T. This implies: –F0(T)/(1 + r)T = p0 – c0 – X/(1 + r)T. So, a short forward position can be replicated with a long a put, short a call, and short a bond.

choices.itemBody: A. short put, a long call, and a long bond.
B. short put, a short call, and a short bond.
C. long put, a short call, and a short bond.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-PM-Conover-04
entry.itemBody: An investor wants to avoid investing in companies that contribute to pollution. In the IPS, this requirement is most appropriately specified in the:

answerFeedback.311b76fc-6d83-4159-8093-dabcd9dd1016: Correct because the unique circumstances section of the IPS should cover any other aspect of the client’s circumstances, including beliefs and values, that is likely to have a material impact on the composition of the portfolio. Such considerations are often referred to as ESG (environmental, social, governance). Examples of ESG issues include environmental issues such as air and water pollution.
answerFeedback.7af06605-09eb-4ed5-b412-976c107db5d7: Incorrect because the liquidity section of the IPS should state what the client’s requirements are to draw cash from the portfolio.
answerFeedback.8ffc0d4c-aa3a-4cc9-8be5-08e04e978d54: Incorrect because the client’s objectives are specified in terms of risk tolerance and return requirements in the investment objectives section.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-08976
entry.itemBody: In bankruptcy, if losses are assessed in accordance with the priority of claims, which of the following debt categories is most likely to have the lowest loss severity given default?

answerFeedback.06875c37-181b-48f8-beb7-2a77e020ca2d: Incorrect because second lien secured debt has a secured interest in the pledged assets that ranks below first lien debt in both collateral protection and priority of payment and unsecured debtholders’ claims rank below (i.e., get paid after) those of secured creditors under what is known as the priority of claims. Second-lien debt ranks above both subordinated and senior unsecured debt.
answerFeedback.475f83df-0863-4179-9e6a-0237e97f2cfe: Incorrect because second lien secured debt has a secured interest in the pledged assets that ranks below first lien debt in both collateral protection and priority of payment and unsecured debtholders’ claims rank below (i.e., get paid after) those of secured creditors under what is known as the priority of claims. Second-lien debt ranks above both subordinated and senior unsecured debt.
answerFeedback.f8f93cf5-91cf-456a-8728-91f2712275af: Correct because second lien secured debt has a secured interest in the pledged assets that ranks below first lien debt in both collateral protection and priority of payment and unsecured debtholders’ claims rank below (i.e., get paid after) those of secured creditors under what is known as the priority of claims. Second-lien debt ranks above both subordinated and senior unsecured debt.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516122
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is most likely a characteristic of real assets?

answerFeedback.3685d1fe-eb5a-45e9-ac03-e691b1a4f425: Incorrect because real assets are characterized by illiquidity, not high liquidity.
answerFeedback.5d96c0f7-e07a-4774-89a1-22dc8c3fe310: Incorrect because real assets are characterized by heterogeneity, not homogeneity.
answerFeedback.83f8ad1b-54a8-4e3a-9c91-e267745425ef: Correct because real assets are characterized by illiquidity, not high liquidity. The heterogeneity of real assets, their illiquidity, and the substantial costs of managing them are all factors that complicate the valuation of real assets.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-04893
entry.itemBody: All else being equal, which of the following indexes requires frequent rebalancing to adjust for price changes in the underlying securities?

answerFeedback.3e85d0c6-9fff-49a9-9af6-e12ea8809aaa: Correct because under the equal-weighted method, after the index is constructed and the prices of constituent securities change, the index is no longer equally weighted. Therefore, maintaining equal weights requires frequent adjustments (rebalancing) to the index.
answerFeedback.cc80ca04-0232-49b4-b4ed-00d1e39ca731: Incorrect because price-weighted indices are not rebalanced because the weight of each constituent security is determined by its price.
answerFeedback.d12474f0-0423-465c-9fc2-2f1c97e77845: Incorrect because for market-capitalization-weighted indices, rebalancing is less of a concern because the indices largely rebalance themselves. Market-capitalization weights are only adjusted to reflect mergers, acquisitions, liquidations, and other corporate actions between rebalancing dates.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Deriv-Lamba-15
entry.itemBody: If a call option is underpriced relative to the binomial model, investors can earn a return in excess of the risk-free rate by buying the call and simultaneously:

answerFeedback.26b73edf-f4a2-425e-aa8b-37bab8df1ef3: Correct because if the option price is too low, buying the call, selling short the asset, and investing the proceeds in risk-free bonds will generate risk-free cash that will earn more than the risk-free rate. This is because a call option can be replicated by borrowing at the risk-free rate and buying the underlying. So, if the call option is underpriced, then investors can earn an excess return by buying the call option while doing the opposite of replicating a call option, which would be shorting the underlying and investing the proceeds at the risk-free rate.
answerFeedback.d8459cb7-3221-4934-8177-e57a320a7ec0: Incorrect because, as described in the rationale for the correct answer, the investor needs to buy a call, sell short the underlying, and invest the proceeds at the risk-free rate.
answerFeedback.e0cbf6f7-dc9f-4863-857b-b22b4bd9ac47: Incorrect because, as described in the rationale for the correct answer, the investor needs to buy a call, sell short the underlying, and invest the proceeds at the risk-free rate.

choices.itemBody: A. investing the present value of the strike price at the risk-free rate.
B. selling short the underlying and investing the proceeds at the risk-free rate.
C. buying the underlying and funding the transaction by borrowing at the risk-free rate.

entry.title: ITEM_20170601046
entry.itemBody: The value of a long position in a forward contract at expiration is best defined as:

answerFeedback.7d7432b4-500b-4d08-8e7f-615a4a1774b5: Incorrect. This is the value of a short position.
answerFeedback.7fea8657-3540-4dd0-b801-a8448f8f7594: Incorrect. The value of a long position in a forward contract does not depend on the value of the forward at initiation.
answerFeedback.851e7314-d83d-49f3-ab0c-2848d1c1b488: Correct. The value of a long position in a forward contract at expiration is defined as spot price of the underlying minus forward price agreed in the contract.

choices.itemBody: A. forward price agreed in the contract minus spot price of the underlying.
B. spot price of the underlying minus forward price agreed in the contract.
C. value of the forward at initiation minus spot price of the underlying.

entry.title: ITEM_20170427076
entry.itemBody: An investor seeking an indirect debt investment in real estate is most likely to:

answerFeedback.1658745e-108b-4786-8d39-aefacecd42eb: Correct because mortgage-backed securities are pools of loans that are securitized and offered to the financial markets providing indirect debt investment opportunities in residential property.
answerFeedback.3c4fbc88-700e-4915-bdde-ffc2452e4d65: Incorrect because commercial property is considered an appropriate direct investment—equity (i.e., ownership) and debt (i.e. lender)—for institutional or high-net-worth investors with long time horizons and limited liquidity needs.
answerFeedback.ec1fdc50-3785-4e45-92ba-637f96ece3e3: Incorrect because originators (generally financial institutions) of residential mortgages are making a direct debt investment in the home.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.06-Alt-Gottschalk-03
entry.itemBody: Which of the following methods of investing in alternative investments most likely provides the greatest amount of flexibility for the investor?

answerFeedback.264f879c-b2ec-4ad1-9b97-a428b55cd0d1: Incorrect because one of the advantages of direct investing is that it provides the greatest amount of flexibility for the investor among the three methods of investing in alternative investments.
answerFeedback.2a04da3d-ff93-4405-b263-1df767019cf3: Incorrect because one of the advantages of direct investing is that it provides the greatest amount of flexibility for the investor among the three methods of investing in alternative investments.
answerFeedback.e1226dfe-93d9-42de-a534-3c6474cda650: Correct because one of the advantages of direct investing is that it provides the greatest amount of flexibility for the investor among the three methods of investing in alternative investments. Direct investing allows the investor to build a portfolio of investments to her exact requirements. Direct investing provides the greatest amount of flexibility for the investor and grants the highest level of control over how the asset is managed. For example, an investor who directly purchases an ownership stake in a business typically has the ability to influence important matters, such as selecting the management team and controlling the strategic direction and investment decisions of the company.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-PM-Glover-12
entry.itemBody: Which of the following behavioral biases most likely helps explain the momentum market anomaly?

answerFeedback.2ef91c3b-5f9a-4532-af48-3816b57fcb15: Incorrect because status quo bias is an emotional bias in which people choose to do nothing (i.e., maintain the 'status quo') instead of making a change, even when change is warranted. While this could be incorrectly interpreted as maintaining a trend in a price, it does not explain the momentum anomaly. Momentum can be partly explained by availability, hindsight, and loss aversion biases.
answerFeedback.4643863e-acf6-48e4-9969-276dd62ae7f2: Correct because momentum can be partly explained by availability, hindsight, and loss aversion biases. Studies have identified faulty learning models within traders, in which reasoning is based on their recent experience. Behaviorally, this is availability bias.
answerFeedback.86ac8ec6-10fa-40e5-8017-1b0a0b5de4f2: Incorrect because anchoring and adjustment bias refers to relying on an initial piece of information to make subsequent estimates, judgments, and decisions. While the current market price may act as an anchor, it does not explain the observed momentum anomaly. Momentum can be partly explained by availability, hindsight, and loss aversion biases.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09010
entry.itemBody: Changes in interest rates due to central bank actions are best classified as:

answerFeedback.09d910c2-0fb8-46c5-8835-c536cfd3c2e5: Correct because systematic risk is risk that cannot be avoided and is inherent in the overall market. It is non-diversifiable because it includes risk factors that are innate within the market and affect the market as a whole. Examples of factors that constitute systematic risk include interest rates. These events affect the entire market, and there is no way to avoid their effect.
answerFeedback.6faf615d-85ef-4f0e-af95-a048b780c73b: Incorrect because Total variance = Systematic variance + Nonsystematic variance and total risk is the square root of total variance. So total risk includes nonsystematic risk. However, interest rate risk is a systematic risk factor.
answerFeedback.cb253439-53b3-419b-97f0-f365bda1389a: Incorrect because investors are capable of avoiding nonsystematic risk through diversification by forming a portfolio of assets that are not highly correlated with one another. Nonsystematic risk is risk that is local or limited to a particular asset or industry that need not affect assets outside of that asset class.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.03-Deriv-Glover-04
entry.itemBody: The replacement of existing trades on a swap execution facility by the central counterparty is best described as:

answerFeedback.3afb3b6c-3e99-4682-b7fc-b32af87db8d9: Incorrect because market making is the function performed by market makers, not the central counterparty. Exchange memberships are held by market makers (or dealers) that stand ready to buy at one price and sell at a higher price. With standard terms and an active market, they are often able to buy and sell simultaneously, earning a small bid–offer spread.
answerFeedback.7b44a6fc-9371-4f13-95a2-c0873fc3aa90: Correct because, under central clearing, a derivatives trade is executed in Step 1 on a swap execution facility (SEF), a swap trading platform accessed by multiple dealers. The original SEF transaction details are shared with the CCP (central counterparty) in Step 2, and the CCP replaces the existing trade in Step 3. This novation process substitutes the initial SEF contract with identical trades facing the CCP.
answerFeedback.816d6f72-2744-49a0-8256-4780446d8399: Incorrect because, at the end of each day, the clearinghouse engages in a practice called mark to market (MTM), also known as the daily settlement. The clearinghouse determines an average of the final futures trading price of the day and designates that price as the end-of-day settlement price. All contracts are then said to be marked to the end-of-day settlement price. Thus, the replacement of trades by a central counterparty in a swap execution facility is not best described as marking to market.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-03134
entry.itemBody: Following an increase in interest rates, the point in time at which a bondholder's gain on reinvested coupons equals the loss on the sale price is best measured by:

answerFeedback.4dc63125-a3ed-4f55-9508-8443c2d0346d: Correct because for a particular assumption about yield volatility, Macaulay duration indicates the investment horizon for which coupon reinvestment risk and market price risk offset each other. In addition, at some point in the lifetime of the bond the effect from an increase in interest rates on the reinvested coupons and bond price offset each other and the gain on reinvested coupons is equal to the loss on the sale of the bond. That point in time is the Macaulay duration statistic.
answerFeedback.c5d73328-6b60-492b-8899-0dabff7f7083: Incorrect because modified duration measures a percentage change in price, not a point in time. Modified duration provides an estimate of the percentage price change for a bond given a change in its yield-to-maturity.
answerFeedback.da943b27-9da5-4994-97a4-20f1dbf67ce0: Incorrect because effective duration measures a percentage change in price, not a point in time. The effective duration of a bond is the sensitivity of the bond's price to a change in a benchmark yield curve.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10508
entry.itemBody: Which of the following duration measures is most appropriate for a callable bond?

answerFeedback.095ff3b9-aa3c-47ca-bbf7-57b8f81c9fc2: Correct because effective duration is essential to the measurement of the interest rate risk of a complex bond, such as a bond that contains an embedded call option. The duration of a callable bond is not the sensitivity of the bond price to a change in the yield-to-worst (i.e., the lowest of the yield-to-maturity, yield-to-first-call, yield-to-second-call, and so forth). The problem is that future cash flows are uncertain because they are contingent on future interest rates. The issuer's decision to call the bond depends on the ability to refinance the debt at a lower cost of funds. In brief, a callable bond does not have a well-defined internal rate of return (yield-to-maturity). Therefore, yield duration statistics, such as modified and Macaulay durations, do not apply; effective duration is the appropriate duration measure.
answerFeedback.5e8e8df2-460c-49dc-a263-60a23b7004a7: Incorrect because the difference between approximate modified duration and effective duration is in the denominator. Modified duration is a yield duration statistic in that it measures interest rate risk in terms of a change in the bond's own yield-to-maturity (ΔYield). Effective duration is a curve duration statistic in that it measures interest rate risk in terms of a parallel shift in the benchmark yield curve (ΔCurve) yield duration statistics, such as modified and Macaulay durations, do not apply [to complex bonds]; effective duration is the appropriate duration measure.
answerFeedback.e297e709-b83a-4f6d-b96f-a0b705a6ddd4: Incorrect because the difference between approximate modified duration and effective duration is in the denominator. Modified duration is a yield duration statistic in that it measures interest rate risk in terms of a change in the bond's own yield-to-maturity (ΔYield). Effective duration is a curve duration statistic in that it measures interest rate risk in terms of a parallel shift in the benchmark yield curve (ΔCurve) yield duration statistics, such as modified and Macaulay durations, do not apply [to complex bonds]; effective duration is the appropriate duration measure.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-04911
entry.itemBody: The price sensitivity of an option-free bond to a non-parallel shift in the benchmark yield curve is best measured by:

answerFeedback.53d93632-bb5d-403e-b848-10f845152173: Incorrect because modified duration is a yield duration statistic in that it measures interest rate risk in terms of a change in the bond's own yield-to-maturity (ΔYield) (not benchmark yield curve).
answerFeedback.9bef153f-afe2-4143-bcae-a089dbc4817e: Incorrect because effective duration is a curve duration statistic in that it measures interest rate risk in terms of a parallel shift in the benchmark yield curve (ΔCurve).
answerFeedback.c6b24950-3805-4e7a-92f7-ef15f775dd48: Correct because a key rate duration (or partial duration) is a measure of a bond's sensitivity to a change in the benchmark yield curve at a specific maturity segment. In contrast to effective duration, key rate durations help identify “shaping risk” for a bond—that is, a bond's sensitivity to changes in the shape of the benchmark yield curve (e.g., the yield curve becoming steeper or flatter).

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Mazur-16
entry.itemBody: For an option-free fixed-rate bond, a change in the spread is most likely to arise from a change in the:

answerFeedback.7423aec7-61b7-49ef-aed7-c5c6296a5305: Incorrect because a change in the expected inflation rate will lead to a change in the benchmark yield, rather than the spread. A change in the benchmark yield can arise from a change in either the expected inflation rate or the expected real rate of interest.
answerFeedback.83f24308-03e9-40fc-945a-a9cf3d3fd61c: Correct because in general, the yield-to-maturity on a corporate bond is composed of a government benchmark yield and a spread over that benchmark. A change in the bond’s yield-to-maturity can originate in either component or a combination of the two and a change in the spread can arise from a change in the credit risk of the issuer or in the liquidity of the bond.
answerFeedback.89ae4a25-66df-454a-9391-e0e19d623ed3: Incorrect because a change in the expected real rate of interest will lead to a change in the benchmark yield, rather than the spread. A change in the benchmark yield can arise from a change in either the expected inflation rate or the expected real rate of interest.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-03611
entry.itemBody: Compared to the market value of a company's equity, the book value of a company's equity is most likely:

answerFeedback.0fa74d16-671f-4d40-8084-82e5b960a035: Incorrect because net income multiplied by ROE is not a measure of company's book value of equity. ROE = Net income / Average Book Value of Equity. Therefore Net Income multiplied by Net income / Average Book Value of Equity does not yield the book value of a company's equity, rather BV of Equity could be expressed as net income divided by ROE.
answerFeedback.28233ec0-29ea-4684-a615-08f2111df52b: Incorrect because the book value of a company's equity reflects the historical operating and financing decisions of its management. The market value of the company's equity reflects these decisions as well as investors' collective assessment and expectations about the company's future cash flows generated by its positive net present value investment opportunities.  Investors' expectations relate to a company's market value of equity, that is the market value of the company's equity, however, reflects the collective and differing expectations of investors concerning the amount, timing, and uncertainty of the company's future cash flows.
answerFeedback.aa01459e-75a2-4d4a-8d65-f9b68b517658: Correct because management's decisions directly influence a company's net income, they also directly influence its book value of equity.

choices.itemBody: A. measured by net income multiplied by ROE.
C. reflective of investors' expectations about the company's future cash flows.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Chan-06
entry.itemBody: An investment-grade bond index is typically further subdivided by:

answerFeedback.126510be-d84a-46eb-b0d8-ff68491e0888: Incorrect because investment-grade indexes are typically subdivided by maturity (i.e., short, intermediate, or long) and by credit rating (e.g., AAA, BBB, etc.).
answerFeedback.50144a2e-1d8d-449c-9cad-7bb3c3cb245d: Correct because investment-grade indexes are typically further subdivided by maturity (i.e., short, intermediate, or long) and by credit rating (e.g., AAA, BBB, etc.).
answerFeedback.cdabe27b-e7f5-4118-9216-84b0ced00961: Incorrect because investment-grade indexes are typically subdivided by maturity (i.e., short, intermediate, or long) and by credit rating (e.g., AAA, BBB, etc.).

entry.title: ITEM_20170427007
entry.itemBody: High-water marks are typically used when calculating the incentive fee on hedge funds. They are most likely used by clients to:

answerFeedback.2392ef09-1f08-4d23-b317-7809acf56e9f: Incorrect because management fees are paid irrespective of returns.
answerFeedback.66d9511c-8a24-40d3-9472-4d54d9dd709e: Incorrect because the high-water marks are not linked to prime brokerage fees.
answerFeedback.efe6eacb-53da-4b87-b4df-ad51cc2c3c0f: Correct because the high-water marks help clients avoid paying twice for the same performance. When a hedge fund’s value drops, the manager will not receive an incentive fee until the value of the fund returns to its previous level.

choices.itemBody: C. avoid paying twice for the same performance.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Kassem-06
entry.itemBody: A 5% semiannual pay bond with a par value of $1,000 is priced for settlement on February 5. If interest payments are made on May 31 and November 30, accrued interest based on 30/360 day-count convention is closest to:

answerFeedback.44a83b8d-009f-498c-b3f3-c9882dde183e: Incorrect because accrued interest is calculated using Equation AI =t/T × PMT. Further, the 30/360 day-count convention often is used for corporate bonds. It assumes that each month has 30 days and that a full year has 360 days. This response uses an incorrect denominator of 365 days and an incorrect payment of $5.  (67/365) × 5 = 0.9178 per 100 par value ≈ $9.18 per bond.
answerFeedback.a6f601b9-98a0-429a-a707-5ab0e64c9e9d: Incorrect because accrued interest is calculated using Equation AI =t/T × PMT. Further, the 30/360 day-count convention often is used for corporate bonds. It assumes that each month has 30 days and that a full year has 360 days. This response uses an incorrect numerator of actual days. (67/180) × (5/2) = .9306 per 100 par value ≈ $9.31 per bond.
answerFeedback.f7901b5c-46a0-43a9-8118-bca196b2dab4: Correct because accrued interest is calculated using Equation AI =t/T ×PMT. Further, the 30/360 day-count convention often is used for corporate bonds. It assumes that each month has 30 days and that a full year has 360 days. Therefore for settlement on February 5, interest will have accrued for two months and 5 days, or 65 days. (65/180) × (5.0/2) = 0.9028 per 100 par value ≈ $9.03 per bond.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Moustra-17
entry.itemBody: The price of a fixed-rate corporate bond with an annual modified duration of 7.15 increases from 92 to 97 per 100 of par value. If the government benchmark yield increases by 5 bps, the estimated decline in the spread over the benchmark yield is closest to:

answerFeedback.1a4d00f5-856e-4faa-a810-93a1a3efdebf: Incorrect because it correctly calculates the decline in the yield-to-maturity of 0.00760 but instead of adding the increase in the benchmark yield to calculate the decline in the spread, it subtracts it, i.e. 0.0076 – 0.0005 = 0.0071, i.e. 71 bps.
answerFeedback.50a5ab84-bf14-4f81-b6ea-ec2fa275b730: Correct because given that the price increases to 97 from 92, the percentage price increase is (97 – 92)/(92) ≈ 0.05435. Using %ΔPVFull ≈ –AnnModDur × ΔYield, the change in the yield-to-maturity can be calculated as 0.05435 = –7.15 × ΔYield ⇒ ΔYield = –0.05435/7.15 ≈ –0.00760, i.e. a decrease of 0.00760. Given that the yield-to-maturity on a corporate bond consists of a government benchmark yield and a spread, the increase in the government benchmark yield by 5 bps implies that the decline in the spread over the benchmark yield is 0.0076 + 0.0005 = 0.0081, i.e. 81 bps, so that on a combined basis the decline in the yield-to-maturity is –0.0005 + 0.0081 = 0.0076.
answerFeedback.fa414cc5-72e7-41fd-b71f-e2e773807c99: Incorrect because it correctly calculates the decline in the yield-to-maturity of 0.00760 but omits to incorporate the effect of the government benchmark yield increase, which means the decline in the spread over the benchmark yield is higher than 76 bps, to have a net decrease in the yield-to-maturity of 76 bps.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606103
entry.itemBody: An optimal risky portfolio has an expected return of 15% and standard deviation of 20%. The risk-free rate is currently 5%. A risk-seeking investor who is considering investing along the capital allocation line (CAL) would most likely:

answerFeedback.025359b5-91f7-4781-8e42-4b8c1618fc60: Incorrect because the investor who invests only to the risk-free assets has the lowest risk appetite.
answerFeedback.02a66bde-d11d-4d01-b8ef-3cab003b91b0: Correct because risk-seeking investors, which are those who are willing to take higher risks for a higher expected return, will invest more than 100% in the optimal risky portfolio by borrowing at the risk-free rate. This portfolio lies to the right point of the optimal risky portfolio on the CAL.
answerFeedback.2b4c7201-6ea5-4dfd-9057-7c1c2809aeee: Incorrect because it has lower risks than borrowing and investing more than 100% to the optimal risky portfolio.

choices.itemBody: A. lend 100% of her wealth at the risk-free rate.
B. invest 100% of her wealth in the optimal risky portfolio.
C. borrow 25% of her wealth at the risk-free rate and invest 125% in the optimal risky portfolio.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-03618
entry.itemBody: Which of the following European options has the greatest value at expiration?

answerFeedback.cb9febe9-f294-47b1-9718-c6f82626fab3: Correct because the value at expiration for a put is the greater of either zero or the exercise price minus the price of the underlying at expiration: pT = Max(0, X – ST), where X is the exercise price and ST underlying price. Here: pT = Max(0,83 – 72) = 11.
answerFeedback.f2ab1b72-2c1b-4dce-aa24-774105ab776d: Incorrect because the value at expiration for a put is the greater of either zero or the exercise price minus the price of the underlying at expiration: pT = Max(0, X – ST), where X is the exercise price and ST underlying price. Here: pT =Max(0,72 – 83) = 0.
answerFeedback.ff294c13-17d8-418a-9e8c-6a4be6ec2f98: Incorrect because the value at expiration for a call is: cT = Max(0,ST – X) where X is the exercise price and ST underlying price. Here, cT = Max(0,70 – 83) = 0.

choices.itemBody: A. A put with an exercise price of 72 and an underlying priced at 83
B. A put with an exercise price of 83 and an underlying priced at 72
C. A call with an exercise price of 83 and an underlying priced at 70

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05013
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a company and its common stock:

Expected dividend per share (D1) $2
Estimated dividend growth rate 4%
Return on equity 9%

Based on the Gordon growth model, if the required rate of return increases from 8% to 14%, the value of the stock decreases by:

answerFeedback.28bfd276-396e-4be3-bf90-a4c9052bb6b1:
Incorrect because 50% is the result when using 9% as r rather than 8%:

r= 9%: V0 = 2 / (0.09 – 0.04) = 2 / 0.05 = $40;

A decrease from $40 to $20 equals a 50% decrease.
answerFeedback.4c5d83dd-3f97-49af-9909-b342554a1e48: Incorrect because 75% is the increase from 8% to 14%. 14% / 8% ‒ 1 = 0.75 = 75%.
answerFeedback.b2f5021a-2afe-4914-85eb-b8ccdcffe410:
Correct because the estimated value (V0) is expressed as:  V0 = D1/(r - g) 

Where: D1 = next year's expected dividend

r = required return

g = dividend growth rate

Under the two required rate of return scenarios, the value is:

r= 8%: V0 = 2 / (0.08 – 0.04) = 2 / 0.04 = $50

r= 14%: V0 = 2 / (0.14 – 0.04) = 2 / 0.10 = $20

When the required rate of return increases to 14%, the value estimate decreases $30 from $50, or 60%.

entry.title: ITEM_20170607136
entry.itemBody: Which of the following most likely has the highest priority claim in the event of default?

answerFeedback.436a3498-834f-4d70-99e7-9efdbc572225: Correct because secured debt is backed by assets or financial guarantees pledged to ensure repayment in the event of default. Therefore, secured debt has a priority claim over unsecured debt and subordinated debt.
answerFeedback.a7d45e05-9e25-4403-933e-a0d32e2d3b57: Incorrect because unsecured debt is paid after secured debt in the event of default.
answerFeedback.e58f03db-b9e6-4b1c-a87b-ab77b98c35cc: Incorrect because subordinated debt is a form of unsecured debt and it is paid after secured debt in the event of default.

entry.title: ITEM_20170607147
entry.itemBody: In a securitization, the seller of the pool of securitized assets is the:

answerFeedback.133a24cf-e5bd-45a3-90a3-7ece13a914eb: Incorrect because the special purpose vehicle (SPV) is the issuer in the securitization.
answerFeedback.2e8fc752-0ec4-4820-998f-17a115837329: Correct because the collateral in a securitization is the pool of securitized assets from which cash flows will be generated. The seller of the collateral is the depositor, also referred to as the originator.
answerFeedback.9f0f4145-456d-47bf-9dee-1c1a2571a770: Incorrect because the trustee is typically a financial institution that safeguards the assets, hold funds for bondholders until they are paid, and provides periodic information to the bondholders.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.08-Deriv-Hambusch-06
entry.itemBody: Which of the following positions gains if the price of the underlying decreases?

answerFeedback.3249b6ac-8166-420a-bc2b-d48f464c47f2: Incorrect because a short forward position, a short call option position, and a long put option position will gain from a decrease in the underlying price.
answerFeedback.364e2032-c2da-47ef-9e8d-d8a814cad428: Incorrect because a short forward position, a short call option position, and a long put option position will gain from a decrease in the underlying price.
answerFeedback.7e946aae-005c-4793-a1f7-789bb8751f0b: Correct because a short forward position, a short call option position, and a long put option position will gain from a decrease in the underlying price.

choices.itemBody: B. A short call option position only
C. Both a short forward position and a short call option position

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-McDonald-20
entry.itemBody: All else being equal, if a company declares a dividend of $1 per share, the company's share price is most likely to decrease by $1 on the:

answerFeedback.6fa928c0-a88f-4659-a6cc-ef5455427858: Incorrect because the declaration date is the day that the company issues a statement declaring a specific dividend. Next comes the ex-dividend date (or exdate), the first date that a share trades without (i.e., “ex”) the dividend.
answerFeedback.85270e95-cc8d-4dba-aee6-479407e6ffb9: Correct because buyers of a company’s shares on the ex-dividend date are no longer eligible to receive the upcoming dividend, all else being equal, on that day the company’s share price immediately decreases by the amount of the foregone dividend.
answerFeedback.c6eeb523-56a3-446a-9833-d7f22cd971df: Incorrect because buyers of a company’s shares on the ex-dividend date are no longer eligible to receive the upcoming dividend, all else being equal, on that day the company’s share price immediately decreases by the amount of the foregone dividend. This is followed by the holder-of-record date (also called the owner-of-record date, shareholder-of-record date, record date, date of record, or date of book closure), the date that a shareholder listed on the company’s books will be deemed to have ownership of the shares for purposes of receiving the upcoming dividend.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Young-27
entry.itemBody: A bond has an annual modified duration of 2.741, an annual convexity of 22.638, and is currently yielding 5.0%. If the bond’s yield-to-maturity decreases to 4.2%, the expected percentage price change is closest to:

answerFeedback.1814ff87-40cd-4704-b9b5-acd0f4bc3bd6: Incorrect because the expected price change is: %ΔPVFull  ≈  (–AnnModDuration x ΔYield) + [1/2 x AnnConvexity x (-ΔYield)2]. This answer fails to include a negative sign in front of the change in yield in the first term to reflect a decrease in yield: (–2.741 x 0.008) + [1/2 x 22.638 x (0.008)2] = –0.021204 ≈ –2.12%.
answerFeedback.4b222fff-e49c-4f91-8a93-a5169bb27600: Correct because the expected price change is: %ΔPVFull  ≈  (–AnnModDuration x ΔYield) + [1/2 x AnnConvexity x (ΔYield)2] = (–2.741 x –0.008) + [1/2 x 22.638 x (–0.008)2] = 0.02265 ≈ 2.27%.
answerFeedback.80d321c8-9ea0-4a2b-bc8f-2f6905f9648f: Incorrect because the expected price change is: %ΔPVFull  ≈  (–AnnModDuration x ΔYield) + [1/2 x AnnConvexity x (ΔYield)2]. This answer fails to multiply the second term by 1/2: (–2.741 x –0.008) + [22.638 x (–0.008)2] = 0.02338 ≈ = 2.34%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-PM-Chua-08
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements about distributed ledger technology (DLT) is most accurate?

answerFeedback.9493f1c0-3a73-4303-b796-482185fbd291: Incorrect because DLT features enable the creation of records that are, for the most part, considered immutable, or unchangeable, and immutability of transactions means accidental or canceled trades can be undone only by submitting an equal and offsetting trade.
answerFeedback.eda333f3-90a4-4dc4-be82-e01d2ba7b093: Incorrect because the processes underlying DLT generally require massive amounts of energy to verify transaction activity, and also DLT requires huge amounts of computer power normally associated with high electricity usage.
answerFeedback.edc73870-b51b-4f86-a96e-29a7d7457db0: Correct because consensus mechanism is the process by which the computer entities (or nodes) in a network agree on a common state of the ledger.

choices.itemBody: A. DLT is considered energy-efficient as it requires minimal energy for transaction verification
B. Using DLT, a transaction entered incorrectly can easily be rectified by deleting the incorrect record
C. A DLT consensus mechanism requires nodes in a network to agree on a common state of the ledger

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10593
entry.itemBody: In which of the following stages of the enterprise risk management process will a company's board most likely identify shortfalls within the company that would cause it to fail to achieve critical goals? When:

answerFeedback.54cc6116-92f3-4b12-ae4e-97054a12a802: Incorrect because risk tolerance delineates which risks are acceptable, which are unacceptable, and how much risk the overall organization can be exposed to. The governance body, often called a board, defines the goals of the organization and, in turn, decides on its risk tolerance. Actively monitoring and managing risk recognizing when risk exposure is not aligned with risk tolerance and then taking action to bring them back into alignment is a feature of the risk monitoring, mitigation and management. Risk levels are continuously monitored, having just been measured. There is a major decision at the monitoring stage: Management must check that all the risks are in line and not outside the limits of the defined risk tolerance or budget. This process involves evaluating the actual risk exposures compared with the organization's risk policies and procedures to ensure that everything is in compliance. If the answer is 'no,' then risk mitigation and management actions need to be taken to modify risk levels and to bring them back into compliance.
answerFeedback.92ca4e5d-7903-40b6-ab2e-30e4cf1e57cf: Incorrect because risk budgeting is any means of allocating investments or assets by their risk characteristics. Risk budgeting quantifies and allocates the tolerable risk by specific metrics; it extends and guides implementation of the risk tolerance decision. While the board provides guidance on how or where that risk is taken (risk budgeting), it is management that allocates capital to risky activities (its business or investing choices) to execute its strategies consistent with the defined risk tolerance.
answerFeedback.d27a7ffa-408b-4c0b-baf0-443524cd4160: Correct because risk tolerance, a key element of good risk governance, delineates which risks are acceptable, which are unacceptable, and how much risk the overall organization can be exposed to. Risk tolerance identifies the extent to which the entity is willing to experience losses or opportunity costs and to fail in meeting its objectives. The enterprise risk management perspective is the right lens through which to view the risk appetite question. The risk tolerance decision begins with two different analyses that must be integrated—an 'inside' view and an 'outside' view. First, what shortfalls within an organization would cause it to fail, or at least fail to achieve some critical goals? The governance body, often called a board, defines the goals of the organization and, in turn, decides on its risk tolerance.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Kassem-20
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about three mortgage loans:

Mortgage Loan Loan-to-Value Ratio Lien Position
1 Low First
2 Low Second
3 High First

All else being equal, the mortgage loan most likely to be classified as prime is:

answerFeedback.16b5877b-4ba7-4e32-9284-c9aadd3993bb: Incorrect because there are two types of mortgages based on the credit quality of the borrower: prime loans and subprime loans. Prime loans generally have borrowers of high credit quality with strong employment and credit histories, income sufficient to pay the loan obligation, and substantial equity in the underlying property. Subprime loans have borrowers with lower credit quality and/or are loans without a first lien on the property. In addition, the lower the LTV, the higher the borrower’s equity. Therefore, because Loan #3 has a High LTV ratio, it would not likely be considered a Prime loan.
answerFeedback.6583db4e-a7fc-476f-95fb-0980837a08d6: Correct because there are two types of mortgages based on the credit quality of the borrower: prime loans and subprime loans. Prime loans generally have borrowers of high credit quality with strong employment and credit histories, income sufficient to pay the loan obligation, and substantial equity in the underlying property. Subprime loans have borrowers with lower credit quality and/or are loans without a first lien on the property. In addition, the lower the LTV, the higher the borrower’s equity. Therefore, Loan #1, with Low LTV and a First Lien would most likely be considered a Prime loan.
answerFeedback.be23e3ec-ca71-49a5-8f78-dcd963d59436: Incorrect because there are two types of mortgages based on the credit quality of the borrower: prime loans and subprime loans. Prime loans generally have borrowers of high credit quality with strong employment and credit histories, income sufficient to pay the loan obligation, and substantial equity in the underlying property. Subprime loans have borrowers with lower credit quality and/or are loans without a first lien on the property. In addition, the lower the LTV, the higher the borrower’s equity. Therefore, because Loan #2 has a second lien on the collateral, it would not likely be considered a Prime loan.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516075
entry.itemBody: Compared with public equity markets, which of the following statements is most accurate about private equity markets? Operating in the private market:

answerFeedback.4336aa4e-369d-4d90-9ce6-3f5685fe38da: Correct because the management of a public firm is under pressures to meet shorter-term demands, such as meeting quarterly sales and earnings projections from analysts. Private owners are thus better able to focus on longer-term value creation opportunities.
answerFeedback.bc683e77-105e-4eef-92ca-6202dee861c5: Incorrect because operating under public scrutiny, companies are incentivized to be more open in terms of corporate governance and executive compensation to ensure that they are acting for the benefit of shareholders.
answerFeedback.f8535478-9dad-4f2e-ba81-229eff473798: Incorrect because public equity markets are much larger than private ones.

choices.itemBody: A. allows more opportunities to raise capital.
B. allows management to better adopt a long-term focus.
C. offers stronger incentives to improve corporate governance.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-01903
entry.itemBody: If the correlation between assets in a two-asset portfolio is less than one, the standard deviation of the portfolio is:

answerFeedback.73a90116-2eeb-4c62-be58-30cb4bb4642a:
Correct because the portfolio's standard deviation is simply a weighted average of the standard deviations of the two assets when the individual assets are perfectly correlated. Portfolio risk falls, however, when the two assets are not perfectly correlated (ρ12 < +1). This can also be seen using the formula for portfolio risk (standard deviation), which is expressed by the terms to the left of the “<” sign below. The term to the right of the “<” shows the portfolio risk when:  ρ 12 =+1

σ p = w 1 2 σ 1 2 + w 2 2 σ 2 2 + 2 w 1 w 2 ρ 12 σ 1 σ 2   <   w 1 2 σ 1 2 + w 2 2 σ 2 2 + 2 w 1 w 2 σ 1 σ 2 =

w 1 2 σ 1 2 + w 2 2 σ 2 2 + 2 w 1 w 2 ρ 12 σ 1 σ 2   <   w 1 σ 1 + w 2 σ 2 .

The left side is smaller than the right side because the correlation coefficient on the left side for the new portfolio is < 1.
answerFeedback.9c6e4b78-7860-47df-9273-86ba68293ec8: Incorrect because the portfolio's standard deviation is simply a weighted average of the standard deviations of the two assets when the individual assets are perfectly correlated.
answerFeedback.efdf576a-b6f3-467f-95da-3e2dbc1c596c: Incorrect because the portfolio's standard deviation is simply a weighted average of the standard deviations of the two assets when the individual assets are perfectly correlated. Portfolio risk does not increase but falls, however, when the two assets are not perfectly correlated (ρ12 < +1).

choices.itemBody: A. less than the weighted average standard deviation of the individual assets.
B. equal to the weighted average standard deviation of the individual assets.
C. greater than the weighted average standard deviation of the individual assets.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-02459
entry.itemBody: In an efficient market, asset prices most likely react to the release of:

answerFeedback.0ec70904-fd36-466e-8c1c-c85f911a6a38: Incorrect because an efficient market is thus a market in which asset prices reflect all past and present information and present information includes expectations. Thus, in an efficient market, prices should be expected to react only to the elements of information releases that are not anticipated fully by investors – that is, to the ‘unexpected' or ‘surprise' element of such releases.
answerFeedback.35bb2602-4779-4eb3-b949-0eea1384980f: Incorrect because an efficient market is thus a market in which asset prices reflect all past and present information and present information includes expectations. Thus, in an efficient market, prices should be expected to react only to the elements of information releases that are not anticipated fully by investors – that is, to the ‘unexpected' or ‘surprise' element of such releases.
answerFeedback.62f635f0-e550-41c7-adea-bedd457d4c39: Correct because in an efficient market, prices should be expected to react only to the elements of information releases that are not anticipated fully by investors – that is, to the ‘unexpected' or ‘surprise' element of such releases.

choices.itemBody: C. both expected information and unexpected information.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-Alt-Burke-01
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a hedge fund:

Beginning-of-year assets under management (AUM) $80,000,000
Management fee (based on end-of-year AUM) 2.0%
Incentive fee 20.0%
Soft hurdle rate 5.0%
Gross return for the year 12.5%

If the incentive fee is calculated independently of the management fee, total fees for the year are:

answerFeedback.2ebac93f-4986-4f30-bb3a-ac3ce24c8973: Incorrect because the incentive fee is calculated only on the return in excess of the soft hurdle rate rather than on the entire return. When a soft hurdle rate is used, the incentive fee is calculated on the entire return. In this case, the calculation of the incentive fee is based on the return in excess of the hurdle rate of $6,000,000 ($80,000,000 × (0.125 gross return – 0.05 soft hurdle rate)). The incentive fee calculated in this manner is $1,200,000 ($6,000,0000 return in excess of the hurdle rate x 0.2 incentive fee). The management fee is calculated correctly as $1,800,000 ((80,000,000 beginning-of-year assets × 1.125) x (0.02 management fee)). Therefore, the total fees calculated in this manner are $3,000,000 (management fee of $1,800,000 + incentive fee of $1,200,000).
answerFeedback.94428028-7cd6-41dd-9694-ccfc52e51a83: Incorrect because the incentive fee has been calculated net of the management fee rather than independent of the management fee. The management fee is correctly calculated as $1,800,000 ($80,000,000 × 1.125 × 0.02). The incentive fee is incorrectly calculated net of the management fee and totals $1,640,000 ([($80,000,000 × 0.125 gross return) – (management fee of $1,800,000)] × (incentive fee of 0.2)). Thus, the total fee becomes $3,440,000 (management fee of $1800,000 + incentive fee of $1,640,000).
answerFeedback.9a69a5f5-a38c-4fc9-9cf6-83e098fc6f4c:
Correct because the incentive fee is calculated independently of the management fee and, since a soft hurdle rate is used, the incentive fee is calculated on the entire return. The partnership agreement usually specifies that the performance fee is earned only after the fund achieves a return known as a hurdle rate. The hurdle rate is a minimum rate of return that the GP must exceed in order to earn the performance fee. GPs typically receive 20% of the total profit of the private equity fund net of any hard hurdle rate, in which case the GP earns fees on annual returns in excess of the hurdle rate, or net of the soft hurdle rate, in which case the fee is calculated on the entire annual gross return as long as the set hurdle is exceeded.
The management fee is calculated on end-of-year AUM of $90,000,000 ($80,000,000 beginning-of-year AUM × 1.125) and is $1,800,000 ($90,000,000 end-of-year AUM × 0.02 management fee). The incentive fee is calculated independently of the management fee and on the entire return (soft hurdle rate) and is $2,000,000 (($80,000,000 × 0.125) x (0.2 incentive fee)). Total fees are therefore $3,800,000 (management fee of $1,800,000 + incentive fee of $2,000,000).

entry.title: ITEM_20170427054
entry.itemBody: Capital provided for companies moving toward operation but before commercial manufacturing and sales have occurred best describes which stage in venture capital investing?

answerFeedback.742bda5c-1882-4b00-975c-177e1f2a1029: Incorrect because later-stage financing (expansion VC) comes after commercial production and sales have begun but before an IPO. Funds may be used to support initial growth, a major expansion (such as a physical plant upgrade), product improvements, or a major marketing campaign.
answerFeedback.8698aad1-3ade-4400-a2dd-ace11d827251: Incorrect because seed-stage financing, or seed capital, generally supports product development and marketing efforts, including market research. This is the first stage at which VC funds usually invest.
answerFeedback.aaeb3ef4-4eb3-4130-b464-b83de05d6f27: Correct because early-stage financing (early-stage VC), or start-up stage financing, goes to companies moving toward operation but prior to commercial production or sales, in both of which early-stage financing may be injected to initiate.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Islam-24
entry.itemBody: Price multiples for relative comparisons are most likely used for:

answerFeedback.6188199d-c012-45b0-9a38-f503613a303b: Incorrect because the major advantage of using price multiples is that they allow for relative comparisons, both cross-sectional (versus the market or another comparable) and in time series.
answerFeedback.83d1639b-a810-4d7f-904c-3395edc01d03: Correct because the major advantage of using price multiples is that they allow for relative comparisons, both cross-sectional (versus the market or another comparable) and in time series.
answerFeedback.d7553036-ba35-4571-945a-b2182d22db44: Incorrect because the major advantage of using price multiples is that they allow for relative comparisons, both cross-sectional (versus the market or another comparable) and in time series.

choices.itemBody: C. both time-series analyses and cross-sectional analyses.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-Alt-Loo-28
entry.itemBody: Under US GAAP, an investment valued using reliable outside broker quotes is most appropriately categorized as a:

answerFeedback.218713b0-510a-469c-b4a7-46db7a21c584: Incorrect because GAAP accounting rules in the United States created a methodology that involves the categorization of investments into three buckets: Level 1, 2, and 3 asset pricing. Level 1 assets involve situations where an exchange-traded, publicly traded price is available and is mandated to be used for valuation purposes.
answerFeedback.8eb20668-e285-424f-8e0c-62c1b707ce38: Incorrect because GAAP accounting rules in the United States created a methodology that involves the categorization of investments into three buckets: Level 1, 2, and 3 asset pricing. Level 1 assets involve situations where an exchange-traded, publicly traded price is available and is mandated to be used for valuation purposes. When such pricing is not available, outside broker quotes, or Level 2 values, may be relied on. As a final recourse, when such broker quotes are deemed either unavailable or unreliable, assets may be computed using only internal models—a process referred to as Level 3 asset pricing.
answerFeedback.f838aa20-00ec-4b5a-9c3b-2ac641cd940e: Correct because GAAP accounting rules in the United States created a methodology that involves the categorization of investments into three buckets: Level 1, 2, and 3 asset pricing. Level 1 assets involve situations where an exchange-traded, publicly traded price is available and is mandated to be used for valuation purposes. When such pricing is not available, outside broker quotes, or Level 2 values, may be relied on.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-PM-Tomter-08
entry.itemBody: Which of the following measures is zero for the risk-free asset?

answerFeedback.17b09333-0d55-4b34-a4e4-c85aab83af5c: Correct because Jensen's alpha does not require the portfolio risk in a denominator. Because the risk-free asset has zero risk and a beta of zero, calculating the Sharpe ratio, Treynor ratio, or M2 is not possible because they all require the portfolio risk in the denominator. The risk-free asset's alpha, however, is zero.
answerFeedback.9b6fb67c-74b5-42eb-9660-73943856b79a: Incorrect because the Sharpe ratio requires the portfolio risk in the denominator. Because the risk-free asset has zero risk and a beta of zero, calculating the Sharpe ratio, Treynor ratio, or M2 is not possible because they all require the portfolio risk in the denominator.
answerFeedback.db1bf3d2-5335-4d6f-92ca-8efa93d14d57: Incorrect because M2 requires the portfolio risk in the denominator. Because the risk-free-asset has zero risk and a beta of zero, calculating the Sharpe ratio, Treynor ratio, or M2 is not possible because they all require the portfolio risk in the denominator.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-07574
entry.itemBody: A buyer's profit from an in-the-money put option is best described as the:

answerFeedback.27fe230b-efbb-45f4-8c5d-3a45876aa7cc: Correct because the profit to the put buyer is Max(0,X – ST) – p0, where X is the exercise price, ST is the price of the underlying at expiration, and p0 is the option premium paid. Also, Max(0,X – ST) is the exercise or intrinsic value at expiration. Therefore, the put buyer's profit is the value of the option at expiration minus the option premium.
answerFeedback.ccee2c05-eb0c-4a11-8bbe-3ef5988e1eff: Incorrect because the profit to the put buyer is Max(0,X – ST) – p0, where X is the exercise price, ST is the price of the underlying at expiration, and p0 is the option premium paid.  Also, Max(0,X – ST) is the exercise or intrinsic value at expiration. Therefore, the put buyer's profit is the value of the option at expiration minus the option premium. Instead, strike price of the option X minus the value of the underlying at expiration ST is the exercise or intrinsic value, not the profit, of a put option.
answerFeedback.da194eac-b460-4118-835b-c766b42682dd: Incorrect because the profit to the put buyer is Max(0,X – ST) – p0, where X is the exercise price, ST is the price of the underlying at expiration, and p0 is the option premium paid. Also, Max(0,X – ST) is the exercise or intrinsic value at expiration. Therefore, the put buyer's profit is the value of the option at expiration minus the option premium, it is not the spot price of the underlying ST minus the exercise price X of the option at expiration.

choices.itemBody: A. value of the option at expiration minus the option premium.
B. spot price of the underlying minus the exercise price of the option.
C. strike price of the option minus the value of the underlying at expiration.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06213
