entry.itemBody: Yield measures for both bonds and money market instruments are most likely:

answerFeedback.78d51f90-dfb3-4524-bccb-1e751cd02ba1: Incorrect because bond yields-to-maturity are annualized and compounded. Yield measures in the money market are annualized but not compounded. Instead, the rate of return on a money market instrument is stated on a simple interest basis.
answerFeedback.aa7b41c5-0cb1-4fed-96d0-44b7dc2b68a5: Correct because bond yields-to-maturity are annualized (and compounded) and yield measures in the money market are annualized (but not compounded).
answerFeedback.aea97a83-2683-48c0-90ca-a798ec34817a: Incorrect because there are several important differences in yield measures between the money market and the bond market: Bond yields-to-maturity are compounded (as well as annualized). Yield measure in the money market are not compounded. Instead, the rate of return on a money market instrument is annualized and stated on a simple interest basis.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-08240
entry.itemBody: Which of the following pooled investment products is most likely to trade at a price furthest from its NAV?

answerFeedback.077ed237-8824-4201-ab6f-364dde5a00ef: Incorrect because an open-end fund will accept new investment money and issue additional shares at a value equal to the NAV of the fund at the time of investment and funds can also be withdrawn at the NAV per share.
answerFeedback.2a4f745f-370d-42ee-91c2-f4ee803de01d: Correct because closed-end funds can trade at a premium or discount to their NAV due to the fixed number of shares outstanding. That is, one consequence of this fixed share base is that, unlike open-end funds in which new shares are created and sold at the current NAV per share, closed-end funds can sell for a premium or discount to NAV depending on the demand for the shares.
answerFeedback.f18d1c10-b25f-40fa-a11b-e8c013dca52f: Incorrect because the market price of an ETF is likely to be close to the NAV of the underlying investments.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Derivs-Agarwal-04
entry.itemBody: If futures prices are positively correlated with interest rates, then futures prices are likely to be:

answerFeedback.486be8fe-5a3a-4593-af91-a2d4da177ce3: Incorrect because a negative correlation between futures prices and interest rates leads to the opposite interpretation, with forwards being more desirable than futures to the long position. Since, in this example, interest rates are positively correlated with equity futures, futures prices will be higher.
answerFeedback.48ec0a00-4ec6-4f9d-bc12-939ffb05dc93: Incorrect because if futures prices and interest rates are uncorrelated, forwards and futures prices will be the same. Since, in this example, interest rates are positively correlated with equity futures, futures prices will be higher.
answerFeedback.718c72f5-7cea-482c-809f-002a2fd8317c: Correct because if futures prices are positively correlated with interest rates, futures contracts are more desirable to holders of long positions than are forwards. Hence the price of the future will be higher than the price of the forward.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06911
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information:

  Standard Deviation of Returns Beta
Portfolio 10% 0.5
Market 20% 1.0

The covariance between the returns of the portfolio and the market is closest to:

answerFeedback.812bf5a5-6bc0-4eeb-baa2-d4a827174aa6: Incorrect because it multiplies beta by both the market standard deviation and the portfolio standard deviation; βp × σm × σp = 0.5 × 0.2 × 0.1 = 0.010. Alternatively, calculating βp × σm = 0.5 × 0.2 = 0.1 or βm × σp = 1.0 × 0.1 = 0.1 and making a decimal mistake also results in selection of this answer.
answerFeedback.c9bc5617-66f6-4acd-aa85-99db240ec654: Correct because the portfolio's beta is calculated as βp = Cov(Rp,Rm)/σm2, where Cov(Rp,Rm) is the covariance between the returns of portfolio p and the market index m, and σm2 is the market's variance of returns. Therefore, Cov(Rp,Rm) = βp × σm2 = 0.5 × 0.22 = 0.020.
answerFeedback.d86bbea5-9bac-463c-bb3c-5a5b9b2dc86a: Incorrect because it mistakes the market variance for the portfolio variance in the correct calculation; βp × σp2 = 0.5 × 0.12 = 0.005. Alternatively, calculating βp × σp = 0.5 × 0.1 = 0.050 and making a decimal mistake also results in selection of this answer.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Chan-25
entry.itemBody: Which of the following valuation models does not require the estimation of required rate of return on a share?

answerFeedback.1ddc1411-9f49-46a1-8b84-94e3c11df0d3: Incorrect because the valuation obtained by using FCFE involves discounting expected future FCFE by the required rate of return on equity; the expression parallels Equation 1: Vo = FCFEt/(1+r)t.
answerFeedback.5eff28ea-4900-4080-ad9e-5a0d9b227319: Incorrect because the Gordon growth model requires the estimation of required rate of return (r) on equity. Gordon growth model as presented: Vo = D1 / r – g.
answerFeedback.a7a5d46c-74bf-4c51-b512-b0a50b940810: Correct because the term price multiple refers to a ratio that compares the share price with some sort of monetary flow or value to allow evaluation of the relative worth of a company’s stock. Discounting and the estimation of required rate of return are not needed in the price multiple model.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2023.06-Alt-Chua-11
entry.itemBody: Debtor-in-possession (DIP) financing refers to financing for firms:

answerFeedback.1cb92ed0-6562-43b2-a496-92a3241bb972: Incorrect because several distressed debt funds focus on debtor-in-possession (DIP) financing, which provides operating funds for firms already in bankruptcy.
answerFeedback.31fdb317-1006-46b9-94d4-a8b84c1990ab: Incorrect because several distressed debt funds focus on debtor-in-possession (DIP) financing, which provides operating funds for firms already in bankruptcy.
answerFeedback.56cead9b-d18b-4b50-b16a-dbced1af0feb: Correct because several distressed debt funds focus on debtor-in-possession (DIP) financing, which provides operating funds for firms already in bankruptcy.

choices.itemBody: B. at the risk of bankruptcy without additional financing.
C. with strong financial positions and promising growth prospects.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Young-17
entry.itemBody: If an investor buys a 5-year, 8% annual-pay bond for 96.11, the bond’s yield-to-maturity is closest to:

answerFeedback.3be1dba7-2683-45fc-a79f-1abeda4915e4: Incorrect because the yield-to-maturity is the discount rate, r, that equates the price of the bond to the present value of the coupon payments and par value. This answer reverses the purchase price and the par value: 8/(1+r) + 8/(1+r)2 + 8/(1+r)3 + 8/(1+r)4 + (96.11+8)/(1+r)5 = 100, r ≈ 7.33%. N=5, PV= –100, PMT=8, FV=96.11, I/Y ≈ 7.33%.
answerFeedback.ad72171a-30db-4636-a113-60fd4e041ded: Correct because the yield-to-maturity is the discount rate, r, that equates the price of the bond to the present value of the coupon payments and par value: 8/(1+r) + 8/(1+r)2 + 8/(1+r)3 + 8/(1+r)4 + 108/(1+r)5 = 96.11, r = 9.00%. N=5, PV= –96.11 PMT=8, FV=100, I/Y = 9.00%.
answerFeedback.c094c9d8-1855-4315-8545-57020ff2009b: Incorrect because the yield-to-maturity is the discount rate, r, that equates the price of the bond to the present value of the coupon payments and par value. This answer computes the current yield instead of the yield to maturity. The current yield is the sum of the coupon payments received over the year divided by the flat price. 8/96.11 ≈ 8.32%.

entry.title: ITEM_20170607114
entry.itemBody: A bond portfolio manager is considering three bonds (1, 2, and 3) for his portfolio. Bond 1 allows the issuer to call the bond before the stated maturity, Bond 2 allows the investor to put the bond back to the issuer before the stated maturity, and Bond 3 contains no embedded options. The bonds are otherwise identical. The manager tells his assistant, “Bond 1 and Bond 2 should have larger nominal yield spreads to a US Treasury than Bond 3 to compensate for their embedded options.” Is the manager most likely correct?

answerFeedback.3134b5b3-132f-4f93-9415-6185814173f9: Incorrect because Bond 2 should have a smaller yield spread.
answerFeedback.a2acd208-6af2-4a17-b1c8-a97a4292fdd7: Correct because Bond 2’s embedded put option benefits the investor, and the yield spread will therefore be less than the yield spread of Bond 3, which does not contain this option or benefit.
answerFeedback.a34fee85-6d2c-4702-beeb-614fded772f8: Incorrect because Bond A’s embedded call option benefits the issuer, not the investor, therefore investors will demand a higher yield spread than on Bond 3 in compensation.

choices.itemBody: B. No, because Bond 1’s nominal yield spread should be less than Bond 3’s
C. No, because Bond 2’s nominal yield spread should be less than Bond 3’s

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-RID-Bailey-Equity-009
entry.itemBody: Posting 55% equity, an investor purchases a stock for €95 per share. Assuming no other activity, if the maintenance margin is 30%, the price below which a margin call first occurs is closest to:

answerFeedback.74a2a7ce-5bd2-4a29-a969-0ce2efe8ea94: Correct because the margin call price is calculated as initial price × (1 – initial margin) / (1 – maintenance margin). This equation is the algebraic rearrangement of the process and formula, where maintenance margin = (initial equity per share + margin call price – initial price). For this trade, the margin call price = €95 × (1 – 0.55) / (1 – 0.30) = €95 × 0.64285 ≈ €61.07.
answerFeedback.96118da6-f8fa-4a56-b480-13e8054301bf: Incorrect because it calculates the margin call price as initial price × initial margin / (1 – maintenance margin): €95 × 0.55 / (1 – 0.3) ≈ €74.64.
answerFeedback.ae0cd819-676c-4898-90e4-ce6c190ab8e3: Incorrect because it calculates the margin call price as initial price × (1 – initial margin), forgetting to divide by (1 – maintenance margin): €95 × (1 – 0.55) = €42.75.

entry.title: ITEM_20170607120
entry.itemBody:
A portfolio consists of four bonds with the following characteristics:
Bond Market Value Duration
A $1.2 million 3.2
B $3.4 million 7.6
C $2.9 million 12.4
D $1.6 million 1.5

The duration of the portfolio is closest to:

answerFeedback.c66f1fab-a78c-4909-93b5-fecd3228702b: Incorrect because it is the median of the bonds’ durations. (3.2+7.6)/2 = 5.4
answerFeedback.fde26e77-dc63-486c-9d85-57d46c5a3cda: Incorrect because it is the arithmetic mean (average) of the bonds’ durations.  (3.2+7.6+12.4+1.5)/4 ≈ 6.2
answerFeedback.feb40d0c-8cb3-4c33-b5a7-73989907f751:
Correct because the duration of a portfolio is the weighted average of the bonds’ durations in which the weight for each bond is its contribution to the portfolio's value, as follows: 

Durationportfolio = Σwbond × Durationbond., where,

wbond = Valuebond/Valueportfolio

 

In this case, value of the portfolio is 1.2 + 3.4 + 2.9 + 1.6 = $9.1 million, and the portfolio duration equals (1.2/9.1 × 3.2) + (3.4/9.1 × 7.6) + (2.9/9.1 × 12.4) + (1.6/9.1 × 1.5) = 0.4220 + 2.8396 + 3.9516 + 0.2637 ≈ 7.5.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.06-Alt-Erickson-21
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is best categorized as a hard commodity?

answerFeedback.b36cfb64-70e6-4030-9678-9264028208ef: Incorrect because commodities are considered either 'hard' (those mined, such as copper, or extracted, such as oil) or 'soft' (those grown over a period of time, such as livestock, grains, and cash crops, such as coffee).
answerFeedback.cbf6fc39-9327-4ad2-aa38-ad837ba5b790: Correct because commodities are considered either 'hard' (those mined, such as copper, or extracted, such as oil) or 'soft' (those grown over a period of time, such as livestock, grains, and cash crops, such as coffee).
answerFeedback.ea74cdc9-cabc-4e77-814e-17594afc6eb4: Incorrect because commodities are considered either 'hard' (those mined, such as copper, or extracted, such as oil) or 'soft' (those grown over a period of time, such as livestock, grains, and cash crops, such as coffee).

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09032
entry.itemBody:
An investor gathers the following information:

Risk-free rate of return 4%
Expected market return 12%
Standard deviation of market returns 20%

The expected return of a portfolio on the capital market line with a standard deviation of returns of 15% is closest to:

answerFeedback.4d5b0c0f-d63e-4202-8286-3452f563a4f0: Incorrect because it is the expected return of a portfolio on the capital market line with equal weights (rather than 25%/75% weights) in the risk-free asset and the market portfolio; E(Rp) = (0.5 × 12%) + (0.5 × 4%) = 8%. 8% is also equal to the market risk premium, E(Rm) – Rf = 12% – 4% = 8%, and it is the difference between the market's standard deviation and expected return, σm – E(Rm) = 20% – 12% = 8%.
answerFeedback.c28360ee-cefb-4af1-81ef-cf381c72568b: Correct because, according to capital market theory, all portfolios (p) on the capital market line (CML) have an expected return equal to E(Rp) = Rf + [(E(Rm) – Rf)/σm] × σp. Hence, for a portfolio with σp = 15%, we have E(Rp) = 4% + [(12% – 4%)/20%] × 15% = 4% + (0.4 × 15%) = 4% + 6% = 10%. Alternatively, it can be deduced from the standard deviation of the CML portfolio that it consists of 75% invested in the market portfolio and 25% invested in the risk-free asset. Specifically, σp = (1 – w1)σm, where w1 denotes the portfolio weight in the risk-free asset and (1 – w1) the portfolio weight in the market, and therefore (1 – w1) = σp/σm = 15%/20% = 0.75. The expected return on the portfolio is therefore: E(Rp) = (0.75 × 12%) + (0.25 × 4%) = 10%.
answerFeedback.dfdf7c72-5349-4e10-97c2-5b11e11027d0: Incorrect because it forgets to add the risk-free rate in the correct calculation; E(Rp) = [(E(Rm) – Rf)/σm] × σp = [(12% – 4%)/20%] × 15% = 0.4 × 15% = 6%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-Deriv-Ebeling-07
entry.itemBody: The value of a European call is inversely related to which of the following factors?

answerFeedback.0d266fb1-76f3-49d3-a869-d14779c66d83: Incorrect because the value of a European call option is directly related to the value of the underlying.
answerFeedback.ab3a77ae-782f-4a82-9baa-d9a7ba203bc2: Correct because the value of a European call option is inversely related to the exercise price.
answerFeedback.c66e94f5-aeff-4213-8506-851585cbab29: Incorrect because the value of a European call option is directly related to the time to expiration.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2023.01-Equity-Young-07
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is most likely forecast by using historical depreciation and amortization expenses?

answerFeedback.2178fae0-d6a6-4c5c-8c7a-c13079f8731d: Correct because maintenance capital expenditure forecasts are often based on historical depreciation and amortization expenses, usually with a small adjustment upward to account for inflation in capital goods.
answerFeedback.2ab11762-f12f-43ce-a60b-ea139d51af2b: Incorrect because growth capital expenditure forecasts are more discretionary and are tied to management’s expansion plans and revenue growth.
answerFeedback.3d2c4382-a9a8-4b36-9278-056bd0196257: Incorrect because leverage ratios—such as debt to capital, debt to equity, and debt to EBITDA—are often used as the forecast object to project future debt and equity levels.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-Erickson-Clone 02 of CFA-L1-00096
entry.itemBody:
An investor sells a European put option with the following characteristics:

Put price 15
Exercise price 250

If the price of the underlying at expiration is 260, the profit for the seller is:

answerFeedback.41f4605a-f958-48c9-9cf9-acd4d1be5f89: Incorrect because it represents the payoff to the call buyer cT = Max(0,ST – X), where ST is the price of the underlying at expiration and X is the exercise price. Therefore, cT = Max(0,260-250) = 10. By contrast, to the put seller, the profit is Π = –Max(0,X – ST) + p0, where p0 is the put price. Therefore, Π = –Max(0,250 – 260) + 15 = 15.
answerFeedback.7a00aef8-a851-4a76-b1f8-a17483b2c98d: Incorrect because it represents the put price p0 less the difference between the exercise price X and the price of the underlying ST at expiration: 15 – (260 – 250) = 5. This would be the profit to the seller of a call option, Π = –Max(0,ST – X) + c0, with the same exercise price and the same selling price.  By contrast, to the put seller, the profit is Π = –Max(0,X – ST) + p0. Therefore, Π = –Max(0,250 – 260) + 15 = 15.
answerFeedback.d7ff718e-f1e5-4e38-9569-2f647801dcc1: Correct because to the put seller, the profit is Π = –Max(0,X – ST) + p0, where X is the exercise price, ST is the price of the underlying at expiration, and p0 is the put price. Therefore, Π = –Max(0,250 – 260) + 15 = 15.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.06-Alt-Fairborn-09
entry.itemBody: Compared to the deal-by-deal waterfall distribution method in alternative investments, the whole-of-fund method is:

answerFeedback.0a9fd39f-91df-4807-8ddb-4025fe6495c0: Correct because the whole-of-fund waterfall distribution method is less advantageous to general partners. Deal-by-deal waterfalls are more advantageous to the GP because performance fees are collected on a per-deal basis, allowing the GP to get paid before LPs receive both their initial investment and their preferred rate of return (i.e., the hurdle rate) on the entire fund. In whole-of-fund waterfalls, all distributions go to the LPs as deals are exited and the GP does not participate in any profits until the LPs receive their initial investment and the hurdle rate has been met.
answerFeedback.2b5af195-cbaf-45a5-a237-c16d11c536b2: Incorrect because the whole-of-fund waterfall distribution method is less advantageous to general partners. Deal-by-deal waterfalls are more advantageous to the GP because performance fees are collected on a per-deal basis, allowing the GP to get paid before LPs receive both their initial investment and their preferred rate of return (i.e., the hurdle rate) on the entire fund. In whole-of-fund waterfalls, all distributions go to the LPs as deals are exited and the GP does not participate in any profits until the LPs receive their initial investment and the hurdle rate has been met.
answerFeedback.8555d522-d900-45ca-8807-521b73c2bd2f: Incorrect because the whole-of-fund waterfall distribution method is less advantageous to general partners. Deal-by-deal waterfalls are more advantageous to the GP because performance fees are collected on a per-deal basis, allowing the GP to get paid before LPs receive both their initial investment and their preferred rate of return (i.e., the hurdle rate) on the entire fund. In whole-of-fund waterfalls, all distributions go to the LPs as deals are exited and the GP does not participate in any profits until the LPs receive their initial investment and the hurdle rate has been met.

choices.itemBody: A. less advantageous to general partners than to limited partners.
B. equally advantageous to general partners and to limited partners.
C. more advantageous to general partners than to limited partners.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Georgiou-24
entry.itemBody: All else being equal, a bond issuer is most likely to be evaluated as less creditworthy than its peers if it has a:

answerFeedback.0ab224d7-1632-42c8-86f4-5abc1b319946: Correct because higher debt/EBITDA shows that there is higher leverage in comparison to earnings and a lower EBITDA interest coverage ratio shows that the company is more likely not to have earnings that are enough to pay the interest (coupon) and thus has a higher probability of default and lower creditworthiness (all else being equal). Debt/EBITDA: this ratio is a common leverage measure. A higher ratio indicates more leverage and thus higher credit risk. Note that this ratio can be very volatile for companies with high cash flow variability, such as those in cyclical industries and with high operating leverage (fixed costs). Coverage ratios measure an issuer’s ability to meet—to 'cover'—its interest payments. The two most common are the EBITDA/interest expense and EBIT/interest expense ratios. EBITDA/interest expense: this measurement of interest coverage is a bit more liberal than the one that uses EBIT because it does not subtract out the impact of (non-cash) depreciation and amortization expense. A higher ratio indicates higher credit quality.
answerFeedback.77c99939-17cc-461d-bc07-5bce83657608: Incorrect because lower debt/EBITDA shows that the company has lower leverage in comparison to earnings and thus has a lower probability of default and higher creditworthiness (all else being equal).
answerFeedback.9011fb9c-83aa-435b-bb45-5b80ae1f0f80: Incorrect because lower debt/EBITDA shows a lower level of debt compared to adjusted earnings and due to higher EBITDA interest coverage there is less risk that the company will not be able to pay its interest (coupon), leading to a lower probability of default and higher evaluation of creditworthiness (all else being equal).

choices.itemBody: A. lower debt/EBITDA and a lower EBITDA/interest expense.
B. lower debt/EBITDA and a higher EBITDA/interest expense.
C. higher debt/EBITDA and a lower EBITDA/interest expense.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B Equity 06KDS
entry.itemBody: An analyst tests market efficiency by computing the serial correlations in security returns. The analyst is most likely assessing whether markets are:

answerFeedback.0981013d-dd83-48db-97a0-f78afdb11716: Incorrect because tests of whether securities markets are weak-form efficient require looking at patterns of prices. One approach is to see whether there is any serial correlation in security returns, which would imply a predictable pattern. Strong-form efficiency encompasses weak-form efficiency and requires further testing of whether investors can earn abnormal profits by trading on nonpublic information.
answerFeedback.70886c21-f69c-475d-84da-fd5c9cc0f943: Incorrect because tests of whether securities markets are weak-form efficient require looking at patterns of prices. One approach is to see whether there is any serial correlation in security returns, which would imply a predictable pattern. Semi-strong form efficiency encompasses weak-form efficiency and requires further testing with event studies that measure investors’ reaction to information releases.
answerFeedback.d4735c49-aa14-4b00-8b30-f36539a0ef15: Correct because tests of whether securities markets are weak-form efficient require looking at patterns of prices. One approach is to see whether there is any serial correlation in security returns, which would imply a predictable pattern.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-FI-Mazur-04
entry.itemBody: In a repurchase agreement:

answerFeedback.b0e1034c-9e1e-4b4c-9997-b567796ffce3: Correct because in addition to the high quality of underlying securities, repos include features designed to reduce the risk of a collateral shortfall over the contract life. One such feature is the provision of collateral in excess of the cash exchanged, known as initial margin.
answerFeedback.b8ee987c-6555-420c-aa1c-9adc4ef0a614: Incorrect because each repo contract participant is exposed to the risk that the other party is unable to meet its obligations, regardless of the quality of the collateral used in the repo transaction. The collateral should have little or no correlation with the credit risk of the repo counterparty in order to diversify credit exposure.
answerFeedback.f812dc1a-6fc4-404b-b91e-3250f27707d7: Incorrect because each repo contract participant is exposed to the risk that the other party is unable to meet its obligations.

choices.itemBody: A. only the lender of funds is exposed to credit risk.
B. credit risk is eliminated by using highly rated sovereign bonds as collateral.
C. the initial margin offers partial protection against changes in the market value of the collateral.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-FI-Kashyap-07
entry.itemBody: The yields of a series of zero-coupon government bonds for a full range of maturities best define a:

answerFeedback.2167a128-9cfd-4775-9455-a37a9ded21d0: Incorrect because in addition to the yield curve on coupon bonds and the spot curve on zero-coupon bonds, maturity structure can be assessed using a par curve. A par curve is a sequence of yields-to-maturity such that each bond is priced at par value.
answerFeedback.2705352d-676f-4ecb-bb09-51f8a6ccbc12: Incorrect because a forward market is for future delivery, beyond the usual settlement time period in the cash market. Agreement to the terms for the transaction is on the trade date, but delivery of the security and payment for it is deferred to a future date. A forward rate is the interest rate on a bond or money market instrument traded in a forward market. Thus a forward curve is composed of a series of forward rates.
answerFeedback.d966bc56-8980-4679-9221-d94583e21d90: Correct because yields-to-maturity on a series of zero-coupon government bonds for a full range of maturities is the government bond spot curve, sometimes called the zero or “strip” curve.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516167
entry.itemBody: An overreaction in the financial markets causes a security’s price to experience a significant loss during a short period. If this overreaction is caused by investors that sell because other investors are selling, the behavior is best described as:

answerFeedback.6e196c8c-fbc3-42db-b9b4-c76bb1aff792: Incorrect because if investors are overconfident, they overestimate their own ability to process and interpret information about a security.
answerFeedback.a5d40c03-ffe2-400b-9463-6022a3aee42f: Correct because herding occurs when investors trade on the same side of the market in the same securities, or when investors ignore their own private information and/or analysis and act as other investors do. Herding behavior has been advanced as a possible explanation of under-reaction and over-reaction in financial markets.
answerFeedback.bd78fd82-3710-4401-b906-e4f874dcbb01: Incorrect because loss aversion refers to the tendency of people to dislike losses more than they like comparable gains. This results in a strong preference for avoiding losses as opposed to achieving gains.

entry.title: ITEM_20170601056
entry.itemBody: Relative to spot markets, a key feature of derivatives markets is:

answerFeedback.3aa29d45-2b03-4cef-a447-050ee2dde756: Incorrect because derivatives markets provide the benefit of ease of short selling to hedgers and speculators.
answerFeedback.5dccb8bd-3c19-445b-ad64-9c6ddcfb1501: Correct because derivatives markets provide the benefit of low capital requirements to hedgers and speculators.
answerFeedback.b9a0387c-5241-4bae-bd3e-6407d82958d1: Incorrect because derivatives markets provide the benefit of low transaction costs to hedgers and speculators.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Equity-Barker-03
entry.itemBody: With respect to margin, the leverage ratio:

answerFeedback.0b4bb02a-87d1-4876-86e1-af47fdc6e763: Correct because the leverage ratio indicates how many times larger a position is than the equity that supports it.
answerFeedback.8d1a1d1e-4ff7-4206-a6d3-fe3f6598a820: Incorrect because the leverage ratio is the ratio of the value of the position to the value of the equity investment in it.
answerFeedback.c4072f30-968c-4ca9-bad9-ec641eef0912: Incorrect because the initial margin requirement (not the leverage ratio) is the minimum fraction of the purchase price that must be trader’s equity.

choices.itemBody: A. is the value of the equity investment divided by the value of the position.
B. is the minimum fraction of the purchase price that must be trader's equity.
C. indicates how many times larger a position is than the equity that supports it.

entry.title: ITEM_20170427080
entry.itemBody: A hedge fund with $98 million of initial capital charges a management fee of 2% and an incentive fee of 20%. The management fee is based on assets under management at year end and the incentive fee is calculated independently from the management fee. The fee structure has a high-water mark provision. The fund value is $112 million at the end of Year 1, $100 million at the end of Year, and $116 million at the end of Year 3. The net-of-fees return earned by the fund in Year 3 is closest to:

answerFeedback.acdc7efe-c5c3-4913-9fee-743901c1bd34:
Incorrect because 11.87% results from calculating the return based on a Year 2 ending capital position (i.e., Year 3 beginning capital position) of $100 million. Instead, the return should be calculated based on the Year 2 ending capital position of $98 million, which is net of fees ($100 million – $2 million).

Management fee = Year-end value × Management fee % = $116 million × 2% = $2.32 million

Incentive fee = (Year-end value – High water mark) × Incentive fee %

= ($116 million – $106.96 million) × 20% = $1.81 million.

Total fees = Management fee + Incentive fee = $2.32 million + $1.81 million = $4.13 million

Net-of-fees return = (Year-end value – Total fees – Beginning capital position)/Beginning capital position

= ($116 million – $4.13 million – $100 million)/$100 million = 11.87%.
answerFeedback.eb69ff59-0420-4d69-aa97-b49e7725832f:
Correct because the net-of-fees return to the fund in Year 3 is closest to 14.15%, calculated as follows:

Year 1:

Portfolio gain = Year-end value – Beginning value = $112 million − $98 million = $14 million

Management fee = Year-end value × Management fee % = $112 million × 2% = $2.24 million

Incentive fee = Portfolio gain × Incentive fee % = $14 million × 20% = $2.8 million

Total fees = Management fee + Incentive fee = $2.24 million + $2.8 million = $5.04 million

Ending Capital Position = Year-end value – Total fees

= $112 million − $5.04 million = $106.96 million

High water mark = Ending capital position = $106.96 million

Year 2:

No incentive fee is earned as the fund declines in value; the high water mark established in Year 1 is not exceeded.

Management fee = Year-end value × Management fee % = $100 million × 2% = $2 million

Ending Capital Position = Year-end value – Management fee

= $100 million − $2 million = $98 million

High water mark = Highest ending capital position = $106.96 million

Year 3:

Net-of-fee returns are affected by the Year 1 high water mark and the Year 2 net capital position (i.e. Year 3 beginning capital position).

Management fee = Year-end value × Management fee % = $116 million × 2% = $2.32 million

Incentive fee = (Year-end value – High water mark) × Incentive fee %

= ($116 million – $106.96 million) × 20% = $1.81 million.

Total fees = Management fee + Incentive fee = $2.32 million + $1.81 million = $4.13 million

Net-of-fees return = (Year-end value – Total fees – Beginning capital position)/Beginning capital position

= ($116 million – $4.13 million – $98 million)/$98 million = 14.15%
answerFeedback.f4d2eebd-0f13-4f85-af00-f0d462b6d40d:
Incorrect because 12.33% results from calculating the incentive fee using the net capital position at the end of Year 2 instead of the high-water mark value established at the end of Year 1.

Management fee = Year-end value × Management fee % = $116 million × 2% = $2.32 million

Incentive fee = (Year-end value – Year 2 Ending capital position) × Incentive fee %

= ($116 million – $98 million) × 20% = $3.60 million.

Total fees = Management fee + Incentive fee = $2.32 million + $3.60 million = $5.92 million

Net-of-fees return = (Year-end value – Total fees – Beginning capital position)/Beginning capital position

= ($116 million – $5.92 million – $98 million)/$98 million = 12.33%.

entry.title: ITEM_20180516062
entry.itemBody: A callable bond most likely experiences negative convexity when the bond’s yield to maturity is:

answerFeedback.6355e62f-09ab-488a-9b44-9f3d426546da: Incorrect because a callable bond is most likely to experience negative convexity when the yield to maturity is less than the bond’s coupon rate (not when it is greater than the bond’s coupon rate). When interest rates are high, the value of the call option is low. When the benchmark yield is high and the value of the embedded call option is low, callable and non-callable bonds experience very similar effects from interest rate changes and both have positive convexity.
answerFeedback.d03273f1-f5ab-4364-91ed-1c33b64a2298: Incorrect because a callable bond is most likely to experience negative convexity when the yield to maturity is less than the bond’s coupon rate (not when it is equal to the bond’s coupon rate). When the value of the embedded call option is low, callable and non-callable bonds experience very similar effects from interest rate changes and both have positive convexity.
answerFeedback.fd44f486-7bb5-41a2-b52e-9e3b57b92baf: Correct. A callable bond is most likely to experience negative convexity when the bond’s yield to maturity is less than the bond’s coupon rate. When calculating the “convexity effect” for the relationship between bond prices and yields to maturity for a callable bond, the increase in price when the benchmark yield curve is lowered can be smaller than the decrease in price when the benchmark yield curve is raised (in absolute terms). This situation creates negative convexity. When a callable bond moves into the range of negative convexity, it indicates that the call option has more value to the issuer and is more likely to be exercised. When interest rates are low, the value of the call option is much greater because the issuer is more likely to exercise the option to refinance the debt at a lower cost of funds.

choices.itemBody: A. less than the bond’s coupon rate.
B. equal to the bond’s coupon rate.
C. greater than the bond’s coupon rate.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-PM-Y.Zhang-01
entry.itemBody: In the portfolio management process, the feedback step most likely involves:

answerFeedback.11407917-be95-4548-aaea-c65314bd8e95: Incorrect because it is part of the execution step, not the feedback step. The portfolio execution step consists of first deciding on a target asset allocation, which determines the weighting of asset classes to be included in the portfolio.
answerFeedback.d449fe2b-e89e-4214-83e7-5f10cb0c8034: Incorrect because it is part of the planning step, not the feedback step. The first step (the planning step) in the investment process is to understand the client’s needs (objectives and constraints) and develop an investment policy statement (IPS).
answerFeedback.f9eb061d-ccdc-454f-952d-2bff6d8c1578: Correct because the feedback step assists the portfolio manager in rebalancing the portfolio due to a change in, for example, market conditions or the circumstances of the client.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-PM-Leonida-02
entry.itemBody: Which of the following approaches to implementing ESG considerations in portfolio construction most likely selects investments specifically based on their environmental or social benefits?

answerFeedback.21d2abf3-8025-4f77-b1be-3e57363ad5f7: Correct because impact investing specifically selects investment opportunities based on their intention to create a positive environmental and social impact.
answerFeedback.29d7d025-c018-43a5-9041-e671cb047282: Incorrect because under the engagement/active ownership approach, investors use shareholder power to influence corporate behavior to achieve targeted ESG objectives along with financial returns.
answerFeedback.427a9957-5d16-48a9-8104-57eab6254751: Incorrect because negative screening entails excluding companies or sectors based on business activities or environmental or social concerns.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Young-22
entry.itemBody: A $20,000,000 par value bond has a value of $23,275,000 and an annual modified duration of 6.39. If the yield-to-maturity increases by 50 basis points, the change in value is closest to:

answerFeedback.593b59a0-774c-4380-a1c4-ab7b05c2d11c: Incorrect because the money duration is computed using the par value of $20,000,000 rather than the full value of the bond: MoneyDur = AnnModDur × PVFull = 6.39 × $20,000,000 = $127,800,000. The change in the bond’s value is incorrectly computed as: ΔPVFull ≈ –MoneyDur × ΔYield = –$127,800,000 x 0.005 = –$639,000
answerFeedback.b754eb25-7951-43c5-a3de-ab2897dadaa8: Incorrect because the money duration is computed as: MoneyDur = AnnModDur × PVFull = 6.39 x $23,275,000 = $148,727,250. The change in the bond’s value is incorrectly computed as: ΔPVFull ≈ MoneyDur × ΔYield = $148,727,250 x 0.005 = $743,636.25 ≈ $743,636. This answer ignores the negative sign before MoneyDur in the second equation.
answerFeedback.e7b8d46e-0f64-49cd-8a66-f955e73a744d: Correct because the money duration is computed as: MoneyDur = AnnModDur × PVFull = 6.39 x $23,275,000 = $148,727,250. The change in the bond’s value is computed as: ΔPVFull ≈ –MoneyDur × ΔYield = –$148,727,250 x 0.005 = –$743,636.25 ≈ $743,636.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-FI-Simsek-05
entry.itemBody: Which of the following asset-backed securities most likely utilizes credit tranching as a form of credit enhancement?

answerFeedback.08fbee78-b02e-44fc-b5d9-d695d752cdf0: Incorrect because covered bonds usually consist of one bond class per cover pool.
answerFeedback.77d8cce3-746f-4ec0-b5b3-2d53be5bf72a: Incorrect because a mortgage pass-through security is an agency RMBS, which is backed by the US government or a GSE and therefore does not need credit enhancement. Agency RMBS include securities issued by government agencies. These RMBS carry the full faith and credit of the government, essentially a guarantee with respect to timely payment of interest and repayment of principal. Agency RMBS also include RMBS issued by GSEs. RMBS issued by GSEs do not carry the full faith and credit of the government, but rather the GSEs’ guarantee of the timely payment of interest and principal for the securities. The GSE’s charge a fee for this guarantee.
answerFeedback.b1220ddb-076c-4874-84ea-0c201f36b032: Correct because credit card ABS typically combine various sources of credit enhancements to support the various tranches. ABS structures normally provide credit enhancements through subordination.

entry.title: ITEM_20170607050
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is most likely a limitation of the yield-to-maturity measure?

answerFeedback.732bbde7-d90b-466f-a4f0-1046d9c0a369: Correct because yield-to-maturity does consider reinvestment income; however, it assumes that the coupon payments can be reinvested at an interest rate equal to the yield-to-maturity. This is one of the limitations for the yield-to-maturity measure because the investor is facing reinvestment risk (future interest rates will be less than the yield-to-maturity at the time the bond is purchased).
answerFeedback.82c9b577-9c0e-441a-954e-567c10cbb060: Incorrect because the yield-to-maturity measure considers the timing of the cash flows.
answerFeedback.f2acfbdc-a661-4588-b1b9-ef20b87e4ac8: Incorrect because the yield to maturity measure considers not only the coupon income but also any capital gain or loss that the investor will realize by holding the bond to maturity.

choices.itemBody: A. It does not reflect the timing of the cash flows
B. It assumes coupon payments can be invested at the yield-to-maturity
C. It does not consider the capital gain or loss the investor will realize by holding the bond to maturity

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-00095
entry.itemBody: The concept of put–call parity best demonstrates the equivalence of:

answerFeedback.66e32209-b0c8-455a-86a5-8264335fd32a: Incorrect because even though the word 'parity' means 'equivalence,' puts and calls are not equivalent. There is, however, a relationship between the call price and the price of its corresponding put, which we refer to as put–call parity. Therefore, the concept of put-call parity does not demonstrate the equivalence of puts and calls.
answerFeedback.8f02576c-952f-4d0a-8065-ff7f8673df4b: Incorrect because a covered call is a position in which you own the underlying and sell a call. But the concept of put-call parity shows that a protective put and a fiduciary call produce the same result, not a protective put and a covered call.
answerFeedback.e70b2f67-065f-47c4-854a-c722eef08a67: Correct because put-call parity shows that a protective put and a fiduciary call produce the same result. That is, c0 + X ∕ (1 + r)T = p0 + S0, where c0 = long call, X ∕ (1 + r)T = discounted value of long bond, p0 = long put, S0 = long underlying asset. A fiduciary call is strategy where the investor buys a call option on this asset with an exercise price of X that expires at T and a risk-free zero-coupon bond with a face value of X that matures at T. The call costs c0, and the bond costs the present value of X, which is X/(1 + r)T. On the other hand, holding an asset and a put on the asset is a strategy known as a protective put, where the put costs p0 and the stock's value is S0.

choices.itemBody: B. a covered call and a protective put.
C. a fiduciary call and a protective put.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Equity-Grabe-15
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is not a source of return from investing in equities?

answerFeedback.1043d9f2-1e80-4136-96af-28fbea8219da: Incorrect because generally, there are two sources of return from investing in equities: (1) cash dividends received by an investor over his or her holding period and (2) the change in the market price of equities over that holding period.
answerFeedback.75903604-760c-4da9-b320-9c96beb204fc: Incorrect because generally, there are two sources of return from investing in equities: (1) cash dividends received by an investor over his or her holding period and (2) the change in the market price of equities over that holding period.
answerFeedback.b4aaf85d-b670-4de9-a723-24bf91dd1206: Correct because stock splits and reverse stock splits are similar to stock dividends in that they have no economic effect on the company or shareholders. They are therefore not a source of returns to the shareholder.

choices.itemBody: C. Change in the market price of equities

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-Equity-Bailey-03
entry.itemBody: Instructions that tell brokers how to settle trades are best described as:

answerFeedback.2fa9c374-e03b-4e52-a200-9b549f618fcf: Incorrect because validity instructions indicate when an order may be filled and not how to settle the trade.
answerFeedback.d1058a08-bbd8-4c4f-95da-6d500c4efc83: Correct because clearing instructions tell brokers and exchanges how to arrange final settlement of trades.
answerFeedback.db899b47-1257-41aa-8bb4-947947570353: Incorrect because execution instructions indicated how to fill the order. They convey how to execute a trade such as using a market order or a limit order. They do not indicate how to settle a trade.
